headline: {u'main': u'Canada Builds a Large Oil Estimate on Sand'}
snippet: This year's rankings of oil reserves included a surprise that grabbed the attention of some industry experts: Canada had leaped into second place, increasing its reserves from 5 billion barrels to 180 billion barrels.    The rankings, both private...
lead_paragraph: This year's rankings of oil reserves included a surprise that grabbed the attention of some industry experts: Canada had leaped into second place, increasing its reserves from 5 billion barrels to 180 billion barrels. The rankings, both private and government, are far from scientific. In this case, the new assessment of Canada's reserves was promoted by a Canadian energy trade group and, upon further examination, turned out to be highly questionable.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Oil Acquisition'}
snippet: Petrofund Energy Trust, one of Canada's oldest oil and natural gas income trusts, agreed to buy the Ultima Energy Trust for about 446 million Canadian dollars ($341 million) to reduce the cost of borrowing money for acquisitions. Petrofund will pa...
lead_paragraph: Petrofund Energy Trust, one of Canada's oldest oil and natural gas income trusts, agreed to buy the Ultima Energy Trust for about 446 million Canadian dollars ($341 million) to reduce the cost of borrowing money for acquisitions. Petrofund will pay 0.442 unit and 17 Canadian cents for each Ultima unit, the trusts, based in Calgary, Alberta, said in a statement. The acquisition will increase Petrofund's production to the equivalent of 37,133 barrels of oil a day and reduce interest costs, the trusts said. The expanded trust will have net debt of 231.7 million Canadian dollars. ''The larger size will improve Petrofund's financing ability and its ability to compete for future acquisitions,'' Chris Dutcher, Petrofund's director of business development, said. The acquisition would also help Petrofund comply with a provision of the federal budget proposed by the Canadian government last week that would limit foreign ownership of oil and gas trusts to about 49 percent, beginning in 2007, Mr. Dutcher said. About 66 percent of the units of Petrofund, which was created in 1988, are held by foreign investors, he said.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA RED-FACED ON NUCLEAR LEAK'}
snippet: Just as the Canadian Government announced this month that it had sold one of its heavy-water nuclear power plants to Rumania, one of its reactors in use developed an unprecedented leak.   The accident in Pickering, Ontario, never threatened public...
lead_paragraph: Just as the Canadian Government announced this month that it had sold one of its heavy-water nuclear power plants to Rumania, one of its reactors in use developed an unprecedented leak. The accident in Pickering, Ontario, never threatened public safety, but it forced a costly shutdown of the power plant and increased criticism of the Government's interest in exporting the reactors to sustain Canada's nuclear industry, which has 35,000 workers. ''The most likely casualty from the accident will be the Government's efforts to export these reactors,'' said Norman Rubin, a spokesman for Energy Probe, a Toronto-based citizens action group that monitors and comments on Government energy policies and programs. The group contends that in its zeal to sell the reactors, the Government has been concentrating on developing countries that are unlikely or unable to apply full safeguards. In general, the group would like the Government to follow the lead of major private companies in the United States that are phasing out reactor construction while stressing projects in nuclear waste conversion and disposal.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada: Scrutiny for Takeovers', u'kicker': u'World Business Briefing', u'print_headline': u'Canada: Scrutiny For Takeovers', u'content_kicker': u'World Business Briefing'}
snippet: Canada will add national security to the list of issues it considers before approving foreign takeovers of companies, Prime Minister Stephen J. Harper said. The change will not apply to takeovers that have already been announced. Mr. Harper’s an...
lead_paragraph: Canada will add national security to the list of issues it considers before approving foreign takeovers of companies, Prime Minister Stephen J. Harper said. The change will not apply to takeovers that have already been announced. Mr. Harper’s announcement follows a plan by a government-owned company from Abu Dhabi to acquire the PrimeWest Energy Trust, an oil and gas producer based in Calgary, Alberta, with properties in Western Canada, Montana, Wyoming and South Dakota. An earlier plan by a company controlled by the Chinese government to acquire a Canadian mine operator provoked considerable controversy in Canada. It was ultimately abandoned.

lead_paragraph: Suncor Energy of Canada and the closely held EHN of Spain are seeking regulatory approval to build a 48 million Canadian dollar ($35 million) wind-power project in southern Alberta. The 30-megawatt Magrath project is expected to generate enough energy for about 13,000 homes, Suncor said. Suncor, based in Calgary, applied to the Alberta Energy and Utilities Board to start construction.

headline: {u'main': u'PETRO-CANADA IS BUYING NATURAL GAS PRODUCER', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Petro-Canada said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Prima Energy for $534 million, tapping into the growing production of natural gas in the Rocky Mountains. Stockholders of Prima, based in Denver, will get $39.50 in cash for each share, Petro-C...
lead_paragraph: Petro-Canada said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Prima Energy for $534 million, tapping into the growing production of natural gas in the Rocky Mountains. Stockholders of Prima, based in Denver, will get $39.50 in cash for each share, Petro-Canada said. Petro-Canada, based in Calgary, Alberta, said Prima had no debt and would have $60 million in cash when the purchase closed in late July. The transaction is at least the fourth acquisition of a Denver-based gas producer since April. The purchase will give Petro-Canada proven reserves estimated at 152 billion cubic feet of gas equivalent in a region that the Energy Department predicts will surpass the Gulf of Mexico as the largest domestic source of the fuel in the next decade.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada: Abu Dhabi Buys Energy Trust', u'kicker': u'World Business Briefing', u'print_headline': u'Canada: Abu Dhabi Buys Energy Trust', u'content_kicker': u'World Business Briefing'}
snippet: The Abu Dhabi National Energy Company, the power generator and oil producer controlled by the state of Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates, agreed to buy PrimeWest Energy Trust, of Canada, for about 4 billion Canadian dollars ($4 billion). Prime...
lead_paragraph: The Abu Dhabi National Energy Company, the power generator and oil producer controlled by the state of Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates, agreed to buy PrimeWest Energy Trust, of Canada, for about 4 billion Canadian dollars ($4 billion). PrimeWest, which is based in Calgary, would be Abu Dhabi National’s sixth overseas acquisition since November. The deal would give Abu Dhabi National daily production of oil and gas equivalent of more than 61,000 barrels of oil in Canada and the United States, the companies said. Abu Dhabi National will pay about 26.75 Canadian dollars each for PrimeWest’s outstanding units and exchangeable shares and will assume about 1 billion Canadian dollars in the income trust’s debt.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada: Suncor Expands in Oil Sands', u'kicker': u'The Americas', u'print_headline': u'Canada: Suncor Expands In Oil Sands', u'content_kicker': u'The Americas'}
snippet: In a move that will make it the country’s largest oil sands producer, Suncor Energy said it would spend 20.6 billion Canadian dollars (about the same in American dollars) to expand operations near Fort McMurray, Alberta. The operation will be ab...
lead_paragraph: In a move that will make it the country’s largest oil sands producer, Suncor Energy said it would spend 20.6 billion Canadian dollars (about the same in American dollars) to expand operations near Fort McMurray, Alberta. The operation will be able to produce 550,000 barrels of oil a day when completed in 2012. The chief executive of Suncor, Richard L. George, said that with the new project, the company expects to generate a 15 percent return on investment at an oil price of $60 a barrel. The expansion will also allow Suncor to use an underground steam heating process rather than open-pit mining for about half of its tar sands oil production, which will reduce the effect on the environment.

snippet: An ambitious project to extract oil from tar sands at Fort Hills in northern Alberta has been shelved, a Canadian unit of Koch Industries of Kansas said today.    The $2.2 billion project was among a spate of oil sands developments in western Cana...
lead_paragraph: An ambitious project to extract oil from tar sands at Fort Hills in northern Alberta has been shelved, a Canadian unit of Koch Industries of Kansas said today. The $2.2 billion project was among a spate of oil sands developments in western Canada. Alberta's oil sands have recoverable reserves 40 times the size of the estimated reserves of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, and the region has been seen as a way for the United States to reduce its dependence on overseas oil.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Uranium Producer Acquired'}
snippet: SXR Uranium One agreed to buy UrAsia Energy for $3.1 billion to form the world's second-largest uranium producer as rising demand for nuclear fuel drives prices to records. SXR, owner of South Africa's largest undeveloped uranium deposit, bid 7.05...
lead_paragraph: SXR Uranium One agreed to buy UrAsia Energy for $3.1 billion to form the world's second-largest uranium producer as rising demand for nuclear fuel drives prices to records. SXR, owner of South Africa's largest undeveloped uranium deposit, bid 7.05 Canadian dollars ($6.01) a share for UrAsia, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, and owns mines in Central Asia. That was 13 percent more than UrAsia's Feb. 9 closing price in Toronto, the companies said. SXR's stock rose 6.8 percent to a record. The combined company, once all its mines are operating, will trail only Cameco in production and be the only producer in Kazakhstan, South Africa, Australia, the United States and Canada, the five largest holders of uranium deposits.

lead_paragraph: Canada's seventh-biggest oil company, Talisman Energy, agreed to buy BP's Gyda oil and gas fields in the North Sea for about 111 million Canadian dollars ($82 million) to expand into Norway. The fields have oil and gas reserves equal to more than 40 million barrels of oil, Talisman said. The company plans to spend about 241 million Canadian dollars developing the fields, which includes drilling wells.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA ENERGY BILL INTRODUCED'}
snippet: The Canadian Government took another major step today to carry out its controversial national energy program by introducing what it called an Energy Security Act into the House of Commons.   In an apparent effort to show that the Government is fle...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Government took another major step today to carry out its controversial national energy program by introducing what it called an Energy Security Act into the House of Commons. In an apparent effort to show that the Government is flexible, the legislation was presented in draft form for discussion during the summer. After hearing comments from all interested parties, the act will be put into final form for action in the fall.

headline: {u'main': u"CANADA CONCERN'S ENERGY PUSH"}
snippet: For 24 years, the Westcoast Transmission Company has been a sleepy, little-known pipeline concern that moved British Columbia's natural gas within this western Canadian province and delivered much of it to the United States border for export.   We...
lead_paragraph: For 24 years, the Westcoast Transmission Company has been a sleepy, little-known pipeline concern that moved British Columbia's natural gas within this western Canadian province and delivered much of it to the United States border for export. Westcoast made grand plans for diversification in the early 1970's. But they were lost, along with 800 billion cubic feet of gas, in the underground flooding of one major gas field that washed out one-third of the pipeline company's daily supply. Today, however, with a new president, new supplies of gas, new and aggressive shareholders and some restiveness among its United States customers, Westcoast is casting about for a new corporate role.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Energy Law'}
snippet: A program to speed oil and gas exploration and development became law today. The law, opposed by the petroleum industry, the United States and, to some degree, the coastal provinces, provides an 25 percent share for Petro-Canada, the national oil ...
lead_paragraph: A program to speed oil and gas exploration and development became law today. The law, opposed by the petroleum industry, the United States and, to some degree, the coastal provinces, provides an 25 percent share for Petro-Canada, the national oil company, in all discoveries not already in commercial production, a move that some in the industry have called confiscation. It also puts federal lands off limits to companies that are not at least 50 percent Canadian-owned.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Plans Energy Shift'}
snippet: Canada will lift Government controls on domestic and export prices of oil on June 1 and is moving to phase out other parts of a national energy program adopted in 1980, according to Energy Minister Pat Carney.   Controls on natural gas prices are ...
lead_paragraph: Canada will lift Government controls on domestic and export prices of oil on June 1 and is moving to phase out other parts of a national energy program adopted in 1980, according to Energy Minister Pat Carney. Controls on natural gas prices are to be maintained at current levels until Nov. 1, when they, too, are scheduled to be lifted, she said in announcing the plans Thursday in the House of Commons.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Energy Talks Progress'}
snippet: Some progress was made in the third attempt this year to settle a major dispute between the federal Government and Alberta over the price of domestic oil and gas and the sharing of revenues, both sides reported today.   But Marc Lalonde, Canada's ...
lead_paragraph: Some progress was made in the third attempt this year to settle a major dispute between the federal Government and Alberta over the price of domestic oil and gas and the sharing of revenues, both sides reported today. But Marc Lalonde, Canada's Minister of Energy, and Mervin Leitch, the Alberta energy minister, warned at separate news conferences that they were still far apart and would need more meetings.

headline: {u'main': u'Big Energy Mergers in U.S. and Canada'}
snippet: Warburg Pincus agreed to acquire Dynegy's natural-gas processing business, and Total of France said that it would buy Deer Creek Energy in Canada....
lead_paragraph: The Targa Resources unit of Warburg Pincus said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Dynegy's natural-gas processing business for $2.35 billion, and Total of France said that it would buy Deer Creek Energy in Canada for about $1.11 billion as high energy prices spur efforts to acquire assets. The acquisition of the natural-gas business is the largest to date for Targa, an energy company based in Houston. The deal adds to Targa operations in West Texas and southwestern Louisiana that include five plants and 2,000 miles of pipelines.

headline: {u'main': u'ANADARKO AGREES TO SELL SOME ASSETS IN CANADA', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, a producer of oil and natural gas, agreed to sell some Canadian properties to the Advantage Energy Income Fund for $142 million under a plan to shed assets and cut debt. The 35 oil and gas fields included in the...
lead_paragraph: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, a producer of oil and natural gas, agreed to sell some Canadian properties to the Advantage Energy Income Fund for $142 million under a plan to shed assets and cut debt. The 35 oil and gas fields included in the sale have proven reserves equivalent to 9.9 million barrels of oil, net of royalties, Anadarko said in a statement. Anadarko, based near Houston, said net production from the fields was equivalent to 4,500 barrels of oil a day. Advantage, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, said the transaction, expected to close by Sept. 30, would help increase its monthly payments to investors by 8.7 percent, to 25 Canadian cents (19 cents) a unit.

headline: {u'main': u'QUEST CAPITAL IN DEAL TO BUY CODY ENERGY CANADA', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: The Quest Capital Corporation said yesterday that it agreed to buy Cody Energy Canada Inc., a private oil and gas company, for about $70.8 million. Quest Capital, a merchant bank in Vancouver, British Columbia, said the transaction was scheduled t...
lead_paragraph: The Quest Capital Corporation said yesterday that it agreed to buy Cody Energy Canada Inc., a private oil and gas company, for about $70.8 million. Quest Capital, a merchant bank in Vancouver, British Columbia, said the transaction was scheduled to close on Oct. 31. Cody is based in Calgary, Alberta.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Energy Company Plans To Split Up'}
snippet: Denison Energy plans to separate its mining and energy operations as part of a plan that may also involve the acquisition of Calfrac Well Services for 228 million Canadian dollars ($177 million). The company, which is based in Toronto, said it pla...
lead_paragraph: Denison Energy plans to separate its mining and energy operations as part of a plan that may also involve the acquisition of Calfrac Well Services for 228 million Canadian dollars ($177 million). The company, which is based in Toronto, said it planned to transfer all oil and gas assets to Denison Resources, while mining and environmental assets and liabilities will be transferred to Denison Mines. Denison Energy, whose assets after the restructuring would consist mainly of cash and tax pools, has the option to buy Calfrac, a closely held oil and gas services company based in Calgary, for cash or a combination of cash and stock. Shares of Denison Mines and Denison Resources will be distributed to Denison Energy shareholders, the company said. All three companies will be publicly traded.

headline: {u'main': u'U.N. Group Advances Project to Transfer Atomic Talks to the Big Five and Canada'}

lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 12 -- By an 8-to-2 vote a United Nations Assembly subcommittee today overrode Soviet objections and approved a plan to transfer the atomic negotiations from the suspended Atomic Energy Commission to private talks among the Big Five and Canada.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Phone Technicians May Strike'}
snippet: The union representing 7,000 technicians has told Bell Canada that it might strike as early as tomorrow afternoon. While the members of the Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union of Canada voted to reject an offer from Bell on July 12, nego...
lead_paragraph: The union representing 7,000 technicians has told Bell Canada that it might strike as early as tomorrow afternoon. While the members of the Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union of Canada voted to reject an offer from Bell on July 12, negotiations are continuing. The union's vice president for Ontario, Joel Carr, said that although the company had given Bell a strike notice, a requirement under Canadian law, a walkout might be avoided. Issues in the dispute include pensions, job security and part-time employment. Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'Canada: Merger of Energy Trusts', u'kicker': u'World Business Briefing', u'print_headline': u'Canada: Merger of Energy Trusts', u'content_kicker': u'World Business Briefing'}
snippet: Penn West Energy Trust, a Canadian energy trust, agreed to acquire Canetic Resources Trust for about 3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($3.8 billion) to cushion the impact of a new tax. The combined trust would have tax pools, or accrued credits used t...
lead_paragraph: Penn West Energy Trust, a Canadian energy trust, agreed to acquire Canetic Resources Trust for about 3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($3.8 billion) to cushion the impact of a new tax. The combined trust would have tax pools, or accrued credits used to reduce tax payments, valued at about 5.5 billion Canadian dollars at the end of 2007, according to the statement. Canetic’s unit holders would receive 0.515 of a Penn West unit and a distribution of 9 cents a Canetic unit before the closing, according to the companies. That values the offer at 15.84 Canadian dollars for each Canetic unit, 7.1 percent above the closing price on Tuesday. Both companies are based in Calgary.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada and India Resume Nuclear Energy Trade', u'kicker': u'Green'}
snippet: Thirty-five years after Canada slapped sanctions on India for using a reactor to help detonate a nuclear warhead, the two countries agreed to resume fuel-grade uranium sales....
lead_paragraph: Thirty-five years after Canada placed sanctions on India for using a Canadian-made reactor to help detonate a nuclear warhead, the two countries agreed this month to a cooperation pact that will see a resumption in fuel-grade uranium sales.

headline: {u'main': u'URS Agrees To Acquire Flint Energy Of Canada', u'kicker': u'DEALBOOK'}
snippet: 6:59 p.m. | Updated URS, a construction and engineering firm, said Monday that it would acquire Flint Energy Services for $1.25 billion, in a bid to bolster its presence in North America's oil and gas industry.     URS, a diversified business larg...
lead_paragraph: 6:59 p.m. | Updated URS, a construction and engineering firm, said Monday that it would acquire Flint Energy Services for $1.25 billion, in a bid to bolster its presence in North America's oil and gas industry. URS, a diversified business largely built through acquisitions, is paying a significant premium for Flint, a Canadian provider of construction services. Under the terms of the deal, URS will pay Flint's shareholders 25 Canadian dollars a share ($25), a 67.8 percent premium to Friday's closing price on the Toronto Stock Exchange. URS will also assume about $225 million in Flint's debt.

headline: {u'main': u'Chevron Unit In Canada Deal'}
snippet: The Chevron Corporation's Chevron Canada Resources unit said today that it had agreed to buy Norcen Energy Resources Ltd.'s interests in a number of Canadian east coast offshore properties. Terms were not disclosed.         Chevron Canada said the...
lead_paragraph: The Chevron Corporation's Chevron Canada Resources unit said today that it had agreed to buy Norcen Energy Resources Ltd.'s interests in a number of Canadian east coast offshore properties. Terms were not disclosed. Chevron Canada said the properties included Hebron, Ben Nevis and West Ben Nevis, as well as other minor properties.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: An Early Retirement Plan'}
snippet: About 1,000 members of the Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union at Bell Canada, Canada's No. 1 phone company, accepted early retirement packages as part of a cost-cutting plan, the union said. Employees 60 or older or with at least 30 yea...
lead_paragraph: About 1,000 members of the Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union at Bell Canada, Canada's No. 1 phone company, accepted early retirement packages as part of a cost-cutting plan, the union said. Employees 60 or older or with at least 30 years of service at Bell Canada, a unit of BCE, were eligible, said Joel Carr, administrative vice president in Ontario for the union. France Poulin, a spokeswoman for BCE, would not comment on the figures but said that details would be released about the time BCE reports its third-quarter results. Workers from other unions and nonunion employees were also eligible for the packages.

headline: {u'main': u'REMINGTON ENERGY OF CANADA IN $84.8 MILLION LAND DEAL', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Remington Energy Ltd., a Canadian oil and natural gas company, agreed to acquire petroleum land in British Columbia from Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. for $127.5 million (Canadian), or $84.8 million (United States), and a natural gas site. The p...
lead_paragraph: Remington Energy Ltd., a Canadian oil and natural gas company, agreed to acquire petroleum land in British Columbia from Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. for $127.5 million (Canadian), or $84.8 million (United States), and a natural gas site. The properties will add 4,500 barrels of oil equivalent a day, increasing output by 28 percent, and 22.5 million barrels of reserves. Canadian Natural is one of the country's biggest oil and gas producers. The site it will acquire is Remington's Buick Creek natural gas property.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA ANNOUNCES NEW ENERGY POLICY'}
snippet: The Canadian Government tonight announced longrange tax and energy policies that hit hard at the largely foreignowned oil and gas industry and the western producing provinces in an effort to increase national ownership, restrain energy costs and m...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Government tonight announced longrange tax and energy policies that hit hard at the largely foreignowned oil and gas industry and the western producing provinces in an effort to increase national ownership, restrain energy costs and make the country energy self-sufficient by 1990. The multinational companies, most of them American, which now own close to 75 percent of oil and gas production, were told that their share would be reduced to 50 percent by the end of the decade through acquisitions and preferential treatment for Canadian companies.

headline: {u'main': u'NABORS WILL BUY ENSERCO OF CANADA FOR $252 MILLION', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Nabors Industries, a leading contractor for land-based drilling, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Enserco Energy Service Company of Canada for 400 million Canadian dollars ($252 million) in cash and stock. Under the deal, Nabors is off...
lead_paragraph: Nabors Industries, a leading contractor for land-based drilling, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Enserco Energy Service Company of Canada for 400 million Canadian dollars ($252 million) in cash and stock. Under the deal, Nabors is offering 15.50 Canadian dollars for each Enserco share in cash or exchangeable shares in a Nabors subsidiary, plus interest from now to the time of the deal's completion at an annual rate of 6 percent. Enserco operates 193 Canadian service rigs and 30 drilling rigs in Canada.

headline: {u'main': u'PHOENIX CANADA OIL OFFERS TO BUY BOX ENERGY', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: The Phoenix Canada Oil Company said yesterday that it would offer to buy the Box Energy Corporation for $239 million in cash or stock. Phoenix Canada plans to offer $12 a share for Box Energy's 3.25 million class A voting shares and $11.40 each fo...
lead_paragraph: The Phoenix Canada Oil Company said yesterday that it would offer to buy the Box Energy Corporation for $239 million in cash or stock. Phoenix Canada plans to offer $12 a share for Box Energy's 3.25 million class A voting shares and $11.40 each for the 17.55 million class B nonvoting shares. It said its offer would be either in cash or a combination of cash and stock. Phoenix Canada, an oil company based in Toronto, did not say when it planned to make a formal offer. While not ruling out a possible sale, the chairman of Box Energy, Don D. Box, said the company, which is based in Dallas, planned to focus on drilling new oil and gas wells. Box's class B stock rose $1.3125, to $9.3125, and the class A shares 75 cents, to $9.25.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada: Energy Firm Is Bankrupt', u'kicker': u'WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | THE AMERICAS'}
snippet: The SkyPower Corporation, Canada's leading developer of renewable-energy projects, sought bankruptcy protection from American creditors. SkyPower is developing  projects in Canada, the United States, India and Panama.  SkyPower listed as much as $...
lead_paragraph: The SkyPower Corporation, Canada's leading developer of renewable-energy projects, sought bankruptcy protection from American creditors. SkyPower is developing projects in Canada, the United States, India and Panama. SkyPower listed as much as $500 million in both assets and debt in documents filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. SkyPower is based in Toronto and is a unit of Lehman Brothers Holdings, which filed for bankruptcy last September. The unit sought protection in Canada under the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act on Aug. 12.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA CUTS LEVY ON ENERGY'}
snippet: The Canadian Government tonight announced financial concessions to the depressed oil and gas industry in a bid to revive exploration and development activity. The tax reductions and credits are designed to increase revenue to the industry by $2 bi...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Government tonight announced financial concessions to the depressed oil and gas industry in a bid to revive exploration and development activity. The tax reductions and credits are designed to increase revenue to the industry by $2 billion (Canadian) by 1986. But no concessions were made to American and other foreign companies that have complained both of discriminatory treatment and of a federal ''grab'' of their potential earnings. Energy Minister Marc Lalonde, reacting to universal complaints from oil and gas companies of drastically reduced cash flows since the National Energy Program was introduced in October l980, declared in a House of Commons speech that the plan ''is working on all fronts and will continue to work.''

headline: {u'main': u'ENERGY REVISIONS PROPOSED IN CANADA'}
snippet: The Government has completed introduction of a controversial package of energy legislation designed to encourage and help finance a reduction of foreign ownership in Canada's oil industry.   In an apparent step to calm critics of the nationalistic...
lead_paragraph: The Government has completed introduction of a controversial package of energy legislation designed to encourage and help finance a reduction of foreign ownership in Canada's oil industry. In an apparent step to calm critics of the nationalistic bills' possible effects on overall foreign investment, which is still a crucial factor in the Canadian economy, the new measures do not include earlier proposals to constrain existing holdings by foreign shareowners. They do, however, allow Canadian oil companies to restrict foreign purchases of future stock issues.

Webb, Acting Secretary of State, said today.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Coal Acquisition'}
snippet: A three-month struggle has ended for control of Fording Inc., the world's second-largest exporter of coal used for steel making, with two competing groups agreeing to combine their metallurgical coal businesses under Fording's umbrella. Under the ...
lead_paragraph: A three-month struggle has ended for control of Fording Inc., the world's second-largest exporter of coal used for steel making, with two competing groups agreeing to combine their metallurgical coal businesses under Fording's umbrella. Under the deal, Fording will be converted into the Fording Canadian Coal Trust, which will own 65 percent of a partnership comprising Fording's existing mines and the metallurgical coal businesses of Teck Cominco of Vancouver, British Columbia; the Luscar Energy Partnership of Toronto; and Consol Energy Ltd, based in Pittsburgh. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'Canada-Korea A-Plant Pact', u'kicker': u'THE MEDIA BUSINESS'}
snippet: Canada's state-owned nuclear power company has signed a contract worth $535 million (United States) to build a nuclear power plant for the Korea Electric Power Corporation.   The deal culminates more than 10 years of sales efforts by Atomic Energy...
lead_paragraph: Canada's state-owned nuclear power company has signed a contract worth $535 million (United States) to build a nuclear power plant for the Korea Electric Power Corporation. The deal culminates more than 10 years of sales efforts by Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd. It will be the second Canadian reactor built in South Korea. Officials said on Friday that the 700,000-kilowatt power plant, estimated to cost about $1 billion, would be built in Wolsong, 160 miles southeast of Seoul. It will be built next to the first Canadian reactor, which has been operating since 1983. South Korea and Canada are each other's fifth-largest trading partners. Trade between the companies is expected to reach $4 billion in 1990. The Korean power company, known as Kepco, has nine nuclear power plants in operation and two more under construction. The Government expects to have 50 nuclear plants in operation in the next 40 years. A turbine generator for the new plant will be supplied by the General Electric Company, along with the Korea Heavy Industries and Construction Company, under a contract to be signed soon, officials said. Construction is scheduled to be completed by mid-1997.

headline: {u'main': u'Biotechnology Pact in Canada'}

lead_paragraph: John Labatt Ltd., Canada's biggest brewery, the Canada Development Corporation and the Ontario government have announced the formation of a joint venture to develop products and processes based on biotechnology. The estimated $100 million project will involve research aimed at the creation of new products or energy-saving production processes, especially in industries with a strong Canadian interest and significant growth potential, the participants said today in a joint announcement.

headline: {u'main': u'4TH REACTOR IS DOWN IN CANADA TORONTO, Oct. 31 (UPI) - The fourth nuclear reactor in two weeks was shut down in Canada today after a leak that released radioactive water into Lake Ontario, officials of Ontario Hydro said.'}
snippet: Officials said the No. 5 unit at the Pickering station near Toronto tripped off without explanation as technicians searched for the source of the leak in the 2,500 heat exchange coils that remove heat from the reactor.   It was the fourth nuclear ...
lead_paragraph: Officials said the No. 5 unit at the Pickering station near Toronto tripped off without explanation as technicians searched for the source of the leak in the 2,500 heat exchange coils that remove heat from the reactor. It was the fourth nuclear reactor incident in two weeks, following problems with reactors at the Bruce and Douglas Point stations on Lake Huron and at a small demonstration plant at Rolphton, Ont.

lead_paragraph: The president of Imperial Oil Ltd., Canada's biggest integrated oil concern, said here today that Canada's new energy agreement with Alberta was based on unrealistic assumptions and did not justify reactivating the company's proposed $10 billion (United States) synthetic oil project at Cold Lake, Alberta, James Livin gstone said, however, that the company had not made a final decisio n whether to abandon the project, which had been delayedwhile the Alb erta and federal governments negotiated the new oil pricing and r evenue sharing agreement. The agreement, reached on Sept. 1, makes some unrealistic assumptions about future energy development in Alberta, Mr. Livingstone said in a speech delivered at the conference of the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Rig Concerns Join'}
snippet: Canada's Petro Well Energy Services Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Crown Well Servicing Ltd. for stock valued at about $11.2 million (Canadian), or $8 million (United States). Both companies make drilling rigs. Petro Well, based in ...
lead_paragraph: Canada's Petro Well Energy Services Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Crown Well Servicing Ltd. for stock valued at about $11.2 million (Canadian), or $8 million (United States). Both companies make drilling rigs. Petro Well, based in Calgary, has 11 rigs and one under construction. Crown, based in Edmonton, Alberta, has 11 rigs. Under the agreement, expected to close by Jan. 30, Petro Well will exchange 9.5 million shares of its common stock for all of the Crown shares outstanding. Petro Well has about 10.3 million shares outstanding.

headline: {u'main': u'TORCH ENERGY TO BUY 25 PERCENT OF GULF CANADA', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., Canada's fourth-largest energy company, agreed yesterday to sell a minimum 25 percent stake to a United States investor group for about $219 million. The group, led by Torch Energy Advisors Ltd., would provide Gulf Cana...
lead_paragraph: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., Canada's fourth-largest energy company, agreed yesterday to sell a minimum 25 percent stake to a United States investor group for about $219 million. The group, led by Torch Energy Advisors Ltd., would provide Gulf Canada with the capital needed to continue developing oil and gas fields. The agreement also gives a group of banks an opportunity to reduce their 70 percent stake in Gulf Canada. The banks received the stake in a restructuring of Olympia & York Developments Ltd., which had pledged the stake as collateral for a $2.5 billion loan. Olympia & York defaulted on the loan when it filed for bankruptcy.

headline: {u'main': u'INDUSTRY COOL TO CANADA ENERGY PLAN'}
snippet: Canada's oil and gas industry reacted with skepticism today to a $2 billion federal tax relief package designed to revive lagging investment and exploration activity.   Energy Minister Marc Lalonde, who announced the tax concessions on Monday, tol...
lead_paragraph: Canada's oil and gas industry reacted with skepticism today to a $2 billion federal tax relief package designed to revive lagging investment and exploration activity. Energy Minister Marc Lalonde, who announced the tax concessions on Monday, told a news conference today that the package represented ''a significant push for industry'' when combined with $5.4 billion in royalty cuts announced by Alberta last month. Mr. Lalonde, who was forced to defend his national energy program in the House of Commons Monday amid calls from opposition Members that it was a ''disaster,'' said the new measures were designed to help smaller companies that needed it most.

headline: {u'main': u'ENERGY BILL PASSES TEST IN CANADA'}
snippet: The House of Commons today approved an energy bill that limits foreign participation in oil production on federally owned lands and gives the Government a vested interest in future revenues.   The measure has been strongly opposed by both domestic...
lead_paragraph: The House of Commons today approved an energy bill that limits foreign participation in oil production on federally owned lands and gives the Government a vested interest in future revenues. The measure has been strongly opposed by both domestic and foreign energy companies and has caused diplomatic strains with the United States Government. After the Canadian Government forced an end to a debate that had gone on for a year, the House passed, 125 to 102, the Canada Oil and Gas Act, which regulates exploration and production on federally owned properties, in offshore areas and in the Yukon and Northwest Territories. The Liberal majority was sufficient to defeat opposition by the Progressive-Conservative and New Democratic parties.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA ENERGY PROPOSAL MET BY DEFIANCE, DISMAY'}
snippet: Several foreign oil companies, reacting with shock and dismay to the energy program presented to Parliament last night by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, said today they would resist attempts by the Canadian Government to increase its owner...
lead_paragraph: Several foreign oil companies, reacting with shock and dismay to the energy program presented to Parliament last night by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, said today they would resist attempts by the Canadian Government to increase its ownership of oil-company assets. The program, calling for increased Canadian ownership of the nation's petroleum industry - now largely owned by American companies - also triggered a sharp selloff of energy stocks in Canada and the United States.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADIAN 88 ENERGY SEEKS TO BUY TEXACO CANADA', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: The Canadian 88 Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy Texaco Canada Petroleum Inc. for $1.60 (Canadian) a share, or about $182 million. Texaco, based in White Plains owns about 78 percent of Texaco Canada. Canadian 88 has be...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian 88 Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy Texaco Canada Petroleum Inc. for $1.60 (Canadian) a share, or about $182 million. Texaco, based in White Plains owns about 78 percent of Texaco Canada. Canadian 88 has been buying shares of Texaco Canada, an oil and gas producing company, on the open market recently. Canadian 88 is an independent oil and gas exploration and production company. Texaco initially offered $1.32 for the Texaco Canada shares but raised the offer in July.

headline: {u'main': u'SUN UNIT CALLS CANADA ENERGY PLAN UNFAIR'}
snippet: The Sun Company's Canadian oil subsidiary, Suncor, charged today that the Canadian Government's new energy policy singled out Suncor for ''the worst kind  of discrimination.''         Canada's National Energy Program, announced Tuesday evening, wo...
lead_paragraph: The Sun Company's Canadian oil subsidiary, Suncor, charged today that the Canadian Government's new energy policy singled out Suncor for ''the worst kind of discrimination.'' Canada's National Energy Program, announced Tuesday evening, would cut in half the price per barrel that Suncor receives for the synthetic oil produced at its Athabaska Tar Sands plant in northern Alberta. Dudley McGeer, a senior vice president and chief financial officer at Suncor, said the company will ask the Government to reconsider its decision.

headline:
{u'main': u'Anadarko Sells Energy Assets in Canada', u'kicker': u'World Business Briefing', u'print_headline': u'CANADA: ANADARKO SELLS ENERGY ASSETS

', u'content_kicker': u'World Business Briefing'}
snippet: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, an energy exploration and production company, said it had agreed to sell its Canadian unit for about $4.24 billion to Canadian Natural Resources, partly to pay off debt associated with its acquisition of the Ker...
lead_paragraph: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, an energy exploration and production company, said it had agreed to sell its Canadian unit for about $4.24 billion to Canadian Natural Resources, partly to pay off debt associated with its acquisition of the Kerr McGee Corporation and Western Gas Resources. The sale excludes Anadarko’s interests in the Mackenzie Delta and other Arctic frontier properties, which remain for sale. Tom Covington, an analyst with A. G. Edward, said Anadarko was trading out lower-growth properties for higher-growth properties acquired from Kerr McGee and Western Gas.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Energy Services Unit Sold'}
snippet: Enbridge, a Canadian energy company, has agreed to sell its retail energy services business to Centrica, a British energy services company, for $620 million, the companies said. Enbridge's president, Patrick Daniel, said the company was selling En...
lead_paragraph: Enbridge, a Canadian energy company, has agreed to sell its retail energy services business to Centrica, a British energy services company, for $620 million, the companies said. Enbridge's president, Patrick Daniel, said the company was selling Enbridge Services to focus on its core business, gas distribution. Centrica North America, a division of Centrica, which is based in Britain, has more than 1.3 million gas customers in Canada and the United States. Enbridge Services provides energy-related services to customers in the Toronto area and central and eastern Ontario.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA NORTHWEST ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30'}
{u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Energy Property Sold'}
snippet: In a move to strengthen its balance sheet, the independent power producer Calpine said it had agreed to sell its British Columbian oil and gas properties to the Pengrowth Corporation. Calpine, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said it would rece...
lead_paragraph: In a move to strengthen its balance sheet, the independent power producer Calpine said it had agreed to sell its British Columbian oil and gas properties to the Pengrowth Corporation. Calpine, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said it would receive $248 million, or 391.6 million Canadian dollars, for the properties from Pengrowth, which is based in Alberta and administers the Pengrowth Energy Trust. ''The divestiture further enhances Calpine's liquidity and financial strength,'' said Calpine's chief financial officer, Bob Kelly. The sale includes about 167,000 net developed acres and 380,000 net undeveloped acres of petroleum and natural gas rights.

headline: {u'main': u'World News Briefs; 2 Energy Companies To Merge in Canada'}
snippet: Two of Canada's biggest energy-services companies, the Nova Corporation and TransCanada Pipelines Ltd., are expected to announce on Monday that they will merge in a deal valued at $9.6 billion.  The merger would be the second-largest ever in Canad...
lead_paragraph: Two of Canada's biggest energy-services companies, the Nova Corporation and TransCanada Pipelines Ltd., are expected to announce on Monday that they will merge in a deal valued at $9.6 billion. The merger would be the second-largest ever in Canada; the biggest deal -- between the Royal Bank of Canada and the Bank of Montreal -- -- was announced on Friday. Officials of both companies said an announcement would be made Monday, but they gave no details. Nova and TransCanada disclosed on Thursday that they were holding merger negotiations.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Anadarko Sells Energy Assets'}

lead_paragraph: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, an energy exploration and production company, said it had agreed to sell its Canadian unit for about $4.24 billion to Canadian Natural Resources, partly to pay off debt associated with its acquisition of the Kerr McGee Corporation and Western Gas Resources. The sale excludes Anadarko's interests in the Mackenzie Delta and other Arctic frontier properties, which remain for sale. Tom Covington, an analyst with A. G. Edward, said Anadarko was trading out lower-growth properties for higher-growth properties acquired from Kerr McGee and Western Gas.

headline: {u'main': u'Digging for Oil; Canada Is Unlocking Petroleum From Sand'}
snippet: Ten building cranes looming over North America's largest energy construction project here are the visible peaks of a $22 billion mountain range of oil investments that are quietly transforming this patch of Canadian wilderness into what may soon b...
lead_paragraph: Ten building cranes looming over North America's largest energy construction project here are the visible peaks of a $22 billion mountain range of oil investments that are quietly transforming this patch of Canadian wilderness into what may soon be the continent's leading oil producing area north of the Gulf of Mexico. Within five years, oil flowing south from Alberta's oil sands is expected to surpass the current output of one million barrels a day from Alaska's North Slope. By the end of the decade, two million barrels a day, the current production of Nigeria, is to be pumped from here into a North American pipeline network that stretches from Portland, Ore., to Portland, Me., helping feed a market in the United States that now consumes about 20 million barrels of oil a day.

headline: {u'main': u'9 STATES AND PART OF CANADA JOLTED BY OHIO EARTHQUAKE'}
snippet: A strong earthquake near Cleveland rumbled through nine states and part of Canada yesterday, sounding an alarm at an unfinished nuclear plant in Ohio and cracking a building in Pennsylvania but apparently causing no injuries.   The United States G...
lead_paragraph: A strong earthquake near Cleveland rumbled through nine states and part of Canada yesterday, sounding an alarm at an unfinished nuclear plant in Ohio and cracking a building in Pennsylvania but apparently causing no injuries. The United States Geological Survey in Washington estimated that the earthquake, which occurred at 11:47 A.M., had a magnitude of 5 on the Richter scale of ground movement and was centered 30 miles northeast of Cleveland. Emergency alarms were activated and employees were sent home at the Perry nuclear plant, 35 miles east of Cleveland. Lee Bailey, a spokesman for the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, operator of the plant, said there was no structural damage. Fuel rods on the site that were to be loaded in reactors were not damaged, he said.

snippet: The European Economic Community might take ''countervailing action'' against Canada because it is holding its energy prices far below world levels, community officials said here today.   Wilhelm Haferkamp, the community's commissioner for external...
lead_paragraph: The European Economic Community might take ''countervailing action'' against Canada because it is holding its energy prices far below world levels, community officials said here today. Wilhelm Haferkamp, the community's commissioner for external relations, told an audience of businessmen and government representatives that, should European companies suffer by competing against Canadian exports ''benefiting from artificially low energy prices, we might be forced to apply safeguard measures.''

headline: {u'main': u'Latest Energy Deal in Canada Is a Plan to Acquire Rio Alto'}
snippet: Continuing a flurry of consolidation in western Canada's energy industry, Rio Alto Exploration said today that it had agreed to be acquired by Canadian Natural Resources for 1.43 billion Canadian dollars ($918 million) in cash and stock after Rio ...
lead_paragraph: Continuing a flurry of consolidation in western Canada's energy industry, Rio Alto Exploration said today that it had agreed to be acquired by Canadian Natural Resources for 1.43 billion Canadian dollars ($918 million) in cash and stock after Rio Alto spins off its Latin American operations to its shareholders. The deal, creating one of the largest gas producers in North America, came one day after Paramount Resources said it would extend its natural gas business by buying Summit Resources for 252 million Canadian dollars in cash. All four companies are based in Calgary, Alberta, Canada's energy capital.

The men were detained on Aug. 14 after an investigation found that one of them was taking flying lessons at a school near an Ontario nuclear power plant.

headline: {u'main': u'NUCLEAR POWER FROM CANADA MAY FILL NEW ENGLAND NEED'}
snippet: As the Seabrook 1 nuclear power plant sits dormant on the New Hampshire coast, three-quarters complete but on the brink of cancellation because of cost overruns, New England utilities are shopping here for alternative power.    The Canadians say t...
lead_paragraph: As the Seabrook 1 nuclear power plant sits dormant on the New Hampshire coast, three-quarters complete but on the brink of cancellation because of cost overruns, New England utilities are shopping here for alternative power. The Canadians say they are willing to provide it by what they see as the most economical and reliable means: nuclear power. The New Brunswick Electric Power Commission says it is prepared to build a nuclear plant whose entire output would be sold to New England utilities for 20 years at slightly more than the cost of production. ''I think we can be competitive in the market, supplying power under terms and conditions acceptable to purchasing utilities,'' said Richard Cote, general manager of Maritime Nuclear, a joint venture of New Brunswick Power and Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., the federally owned reactor-building concern. Meeting the U.S. Market ''In the future, you wouldn't have to stretch the case too far to say you could build units in the Maritimes to meet the market in the U.S.,'' Mr. Cote said in an interview at his office here.

headline: {u'main': u'THE U.S.-CANADA POWER BOND'}
snippet: Canada and the United States, which have two of the world's most closely connected economies, are being drawn even closer together in the energy field these days by rapidly growing new links in electricity.   Vast amounts of electrical energy, mos...
lead_paragraph: Canada and the United States, which have two of the world's most closely connected economies, are being drawn even closer together in the energy field these days by rapidly growing new links in electricity. Vast amounts of electrical energy, most of it heading south, are flowing on new transmission lines across the 3,986.8-mile-long border between the two countries. Some experts predict that the two-way trade in this energy will exceed $10 billion by the end of the decade, compared with less than $800 million now. ''The idea has been around a long time,'' said one American diplomat, ''but the interest is suddenly growing now. It's really astounding.''

headline: {u'main': u'Ceausescu to Cut Short His Visit to Canada', u'kicker': u'AROUND THE WORLD'}

lead_paragraph: Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, is cutting short his visit to Canada because a tour of a nuclear plant near Toronto could not be arranged, a senior Canadian official said today. Mr. Ceausescu was scheduled to go to the nuclear plant and to visit Toronto on Wednesday. A spokesman for Ontario Hydro, which operates the plant, said a labor dispute had made security arrangements too complicated.

lead_paragraph: The Penn West Energy Trust has agreed to buy the Petrofund Energy Trust for 2.99 billion Canadian dollars ($2.61 billion) to create Canada's largest energy trust by sales. Both trusts are based in Calgary, Alberta.

headline: {u'main': u'Reactor Leaks Tritium At a Station in Canada'}
snippet: A nuclear reactor in Pickering, Ontario, leaked a small amount of radioactive tritium after an accident that began Monday, the Canadian authorities announced yesterday, prompting officials in Ontario and in New York State to step up air sampling. ...
lead_paragraph: A nuclear reactor in Pickering, Ontario, leaked a small amount of radioactive tritium after an accident that began Monday, the Canadian authorities announced yesterday, prompting officials in Ontario and in New York State to step up air sampling. The Ministry of Labor for the province of Ontario notified the New York State Health Department by telephone yesterday morning that the reactor, which is east of Toronto, on Lake Ontario, had leaked about 16 curies of tritium, which the ministry said ''slightly exceeded one percent of the release limit'' set by the authorities.

snippet: To the Editor:    In your Aug. 3 editorial ''The Chill From Dear Canada'' you took a welcome moderate stance. Even so, the statement that ''Mr. Trudeau aims to unite the country against a common enemy'' (implicitly the United States) is an assumpt...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In your Aug. 3 editorial ''The Chill From Dear Canada'' you took a welcome moderate stance. Even so, the statement that ''Mr. Trudeau aims to unite the country against a common enemy'' (implicitly the United States) is an assumption that it may not be necessary to make. Actions that we may read spontaneously as anti-American may, when placed within Canada's political and historical context, appear moderate and possibly even justifiable. For international business, that context is currently shaped by two factors: the facts on foreign ownership and the public perception of it.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Power Stations Acquired'}
snippet: Shell Generating and Bechtel Enterprises Energy agreed to sell 10 electrical power generating stations to the Toronto-based Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan and A.I.G. Highstar Capital II, an equity fund led by the A.I.G. Global Investment Group, pa...
lead_paragraph: Shell Generating and Bechtel Enterprises Energy agreed to sell 10 electrical power generating stations to the Toronto-based Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan and A.I.G. Highstar Capital II, an equity fund led by the A.I.G. Global Investment Group, part of American International Group. The $1.7 billion transaction includes generating stations that produce about 5,500 megawatts of electricity in Mexico, China, Australia, Britain and the Netherlands. The plants are currently held by a partnership known as InterGen that is 68 percent owned by Shell Generating, a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. InterGen said it would retain ownership of its power plants in the United States, Colombia and Turkey ''pending further review.'' It added that those operations would be reorganized. Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Lights Out for Inefficient Bulbs'}
snippet: Canada will ban inefficient light bulbs within five years, the natural resources minister, Gary Lunn, said. The decision follows a similar move by Australia and by Canada's most populous province, Ontario. Regulations for the ban, which will not b...
lead_paragraph: Canada will ban inefficient light bulbs within five years, the natural resources minister, Gary Lunn, said. The decision follows a similar move by Australia and by Canada's most populous province, Ontario. Regulations for the ban, which will not be available until later this year, will require bulbs to meet minimum efficiency standards. While that will remove traditional incandescent bulbs from store shelves, it may also affect other technologies, like bulbs filled with halogen gas. IAN AUSTEN

lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, May 30 Persistent demands by the Nixon Administration that Canada negotiate a common policy for the use of North American energy sources oil, coat, gas, uranium and hydropower are meeting increasing resistance here. They are also causing a rare outburst of nationalism that Canadians normally hold in reserve.

snippet: A federal judge cleared the way today for the shipment of plutonium from Los Alamos, N.M., to Canada by refusing to grant an injunction to groups that say the move is illegal.    The order from Judge Richard A. Enslen of United States District Cou...
lead_paragraph: A federal judge cleared the way today for the shipment of plutonium from Los Alamos, N.M., to Canada by refusing to grant an injunction to groups that say the move is illegal. The order from Judge Richard A. Enslen of United States District Court in the western district of Michigan allows the Department of Energy to truck nine fuel rods to an experimental reactor in Chalk River, in southeastern Ontario. It was unclear when they would be moved.

headline: {u'main': u'CLOSE MONITORING IN U.S. AND CANADA', u'kicker': u'NUCLEAR DISASTER: THE CONSEQUENCES'}
snippet: The United States and Canada took steps yesterday to provide early warning of any increase in North American atmospheric radioactivity resulting from the Soviet nuclear accident.   In Washington, officials of the Environmental Protection Agency sa...
lead_paragraph: The United States and Canada took steps yesterday to provide early warning of any increase in North American atmospheric radioactivity resulting from the Soviet nuclear accident. In Washington, officials of the Environmental Protection Agency said it began checking its national network of radiation monitoring stations daily instead of the usual twice a week, In Canada, the Department of Health and Welfare has also begun daily monitoring instead of the usual weekly monitoring. Bliss Tracy, a spokesman, said, ''The fact that radiation was detected in Scandinavia would lead us to believe enough is there so that some will reach Canada.'' But he added that the level of contamination was not considered likely to rise high enough to warrant protective action.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA REAFFIRMS FUELS PLAN'}
snippet: The Government tonight reaffirmed its national energy program as ''a great Canadian undertaking,'' but added that the special measures being employed to achieve more Canadian ownership of the oil and gas companies would not be extended to other se...
lead_paragraph: The Government tonight reaffirmed its national energy program as ''a great Canadian undertaking,'' but added that the special measures being employed to achieve more Canadian ownership of the oil and gas companies would not be extended to other sectors. The statement, in a document that accompanied the budget message to the House of Commons, appeared to extend an olive branch to American critics who have complained that Canadian foreign investment policies are restrictive. In a defeat for Canadian economic nationalists, some plans to strengthen the Foreign Investment Review Agency were indefinitely shelved.

headline: {u'main': u"Oil Resources Up in Canada OTTAWA, Jan. 23 (Reuters) - Canada's conventional oil resources are estimated at 38 billion barrels, up from 30 billion barrels in 1976, the Energy Department said today."}

The latest estimate there is 13 billion barrels, up threefold from 4.33 billion barrels in 1976. Canada's potential oil and natural gas resources are large and could assure self-sufficiency if means can be found to convert a significant portion of them into economic reserves, according to the he report, compiled by the Geological Survey of Canada.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Inflation Slows'}
snippet: Canada's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, slowed to 2.6 percent for the year to July, Statistics Canada reported. The drop, from 3.3 percent in June and 3.9 percent in May, was largely because of lower energy prices, including...
lead_paragraph: Canada's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, slowed to 2.6 percent for the year to July, Statistics Canada reported. The drop, from 3.3 percent in June and 3.9 percent in May, was largely because of lower energy prices, including a 9.6 percent drop in gasoline and an 8.4 percent decline in natural gas. Cheaper energy bills were partly offset by a 4.6 percent rise in food prices. Excluding food, energy and other volatile items, the core rate rose 2.4 percent in July, within the Bank of Canada's range of 1 percent to 3 percent. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Studies Oil-Aid Plan'}

lead_paragraph: Venezuela's Minister of Energy and Mines, Humberto Calderon Berti, will visit Canada in October for talks on a plan to assist developing countries in the Western Hemisphere, a Government official said today. Ignacio Moreno Leon, Venezuela's deputy energy and mines minister, told reporters that Canada was interested in forming a hemispheric energy-assistance program similar to one recently begun by Venezuela and Mexico.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Increases Offer on Oil Sands'}

lead_paragraph: Canada's federal Energy Minister, Marc Lalonde, has raised the federal offer for production from new oil-sands plants, an official of the Alberta government said today. The new offer is $38 (Canadian) a barrel plus escalation for consumer prices, compared with the previous offer of $32 a barrel plus escalation, a spokesman for the Alberta Energy Minister, Merv Leitch, said. A Canadian dollar is worth about 85 cents in United States currency.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Reaches Oil Agreements'}
snippet: The Canadian federal Government concluded oil exploration agreements worth $263 million (in Canadian currency) under which Shell Canada Resources Ltd. would drill six deep-water wells along the Scotian Shelf, Energy Minister Marc Lalonde announced...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian federal Government concluded oil exploration agreements worth $263 million (in Canadian currency) under which Shell Canada Resources Ltd. would drill six deep-water wells along the Scotian Shelf, Energy Minister Marc Lalonde announced. The accord is the first signed under the energy exploration regime agreed on by Nova Scotia province and the federal Government. Mr. Lalonde said that when the full interests in farm-out agreements had been earned, the present Canadian ownership rate should rise to 29.6 percent from its present 6.28 percent. When those arrangements are completed, he said, the working interest on most of the blocks covered in the agreements should be Shell Canada Resources, 50 percent; Shell Explorer Ltd., 25 percent; Canterra Energy Ltd., 12.5 percent; and Norcen Energy Resources Ltd., 12.5 percent.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA INFLATION INCREASES', u'kicker': u'WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS'}
snippet: Canada's annual inflation rate was 2.9 percent in June, up from 2.4 percent in May, and stronger than many economists had expected. Energy again supplied most of the cost pressure, with gasoline prices rising 6.3 percent in June, to stand 30.5 per...
lead_paragraph: Canada's annual inflation rate was 2.9 percent in June, up from 2.4 percent in May, and stronger than many economists had expected. Energy again supplied most of the cost pressure, with gasoline prices rising 6.3 percent in June, to stand 30.5 percent higher than a year earlier. Excluding energy, consumer prices advanced 1.4 percent in June. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'Canada: Prices Fall Sharply', u'kicker': u'WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | THE AMERICAS'}
snippet: Consumer prices in Canada fell at the steepest rate in 56 years in July because of a sharp decline in energy costs. But analysts said there was little risk of prolonged deflation. Overall prices dropped 0.9 percent year-on-year in July, according ...
lead_paragraph: Consumer prices in Canada fell at the steepest rate in 56 years in July because of a sharp decline in energy costs. But analysts said there was little risk of prolonged deflation. Overall prices dropped 0.9 percent year-on-year in July, according to Statistics Canada. That reflected a 23.4 percent decline in energy prices. In July 1953, prices fell 1.4 percent. The Bank of Canada's target is about 2 percent annual inflation.

headline: {u'main': u'INFLATION UP IN CANADA', u'kicker': u'WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS'}
snippet: The annual rate of inflation in Canada, as measured by the consumer price index, was 2.6 percent in December, up from 2.2 percent in November, Statistics Canada reported. Higher prices for oil and gas accounted for most of the increase. Excluding ...
lead_paragraph: The annual rate of inflation in Canada, as measured by the consumer price index, was 2.6 percent in December, up from 2.2 percent in November, Statistics Canada reported. Higher prices for oil and gas accounted for most of the increase. Excluding energy, prices were only 1.6 percent higher than a year ago. For the last nine months, consumer price inflation excluding energy has been 1.5 or 1.6 percent. Timothy Pritchard

Duncan Jr., United States Secretary of Energy, produced an "understanding" today on pricing for future Canadian exports of natural gas to the United States. Mr. Lalonde said the present export price of $4.47 per 1,000 cubic feet would remain in effect.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Warned On Oil Sands'}
snippet: Canada's national energy program has probably delayed development of two major oil sands projects in northern Alberta by at least two years and is bound to cut production, Texaco Canada's chairman, Robert Sparks, said today.   He told a hearing co...
lead_paragraph: Canada's national energy program has probably delayed development of two major oil sands projects in northern Alberta by at least two years and is bound to cut production, Texaco Canada's chairman, Robert Sparks, said today. He told a hearing conducted by the National Energy Board that the delays would likely result in a loss of 200 million barrels of oil production and cost Canadians $18 billion (Canadian) more in oil imports needed to meet domestic demand.

headline: {u'main': u'Oil Tax Shift Seen in Canada'}
snippet: Federal Energy Minister Marc Lalonde said today that the forthcoming Canadian budget would do away with the tax deferrals now widely used by resource companies. He told an industry audience that the budget, expected in the third week of October, w...
lead_paragraph: Federal Energy Minister Marc Lalonde said today that the forthcoming Canadian budget would do away with the tax deferrals now widely used by resource companies. He told an industry audience that the budget, expected in the third week of October, would turn ''upside down'' the existing tax system as it applies to the petroleum industry. This implies a drastic revision of the corporate tax system in Canada, which allows tax exemptions as long as a company reinvests its profits.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Forms Oil Agency'}
snippet: The Canadian Government announced today the formation of a Petroleum Monitoring Agency to inquire into the profits, investments and use of Canadian resources by the largely foreign-owned oil industry.         The new agency would have the investig...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Government announced today the formation of a Petroleum Monitoring Agency to inquire into the profits, investments and use of Canadian resources by the largely foreign-owned oil industry. The new agency would have the investigatory powers of an official commission and would make recommendations to the Government. The Government would presumably base some taxing policies on the agency's findings. Marc Lalonde, Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources, said the Ministry of Finance was looking into an excess profits tax on oil as one way of raising revenue, but he added that industry needs for reinvestment would also have to be considered. He said that a report to be issued soon on 1979 oil industry profits would justify the agency.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA: INFLATION FALLS', u'kicker': u'WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS'}
snippet: Canada's annual inflation rate fell for a fourth consecutive month, dropping to 2.5 percent in March from 2.9 percent in February. Excluding energy and food costs, core inflation rose at a1.7 percent annual rate last month, compared with 2 percent...
lead_paragraph: Canada's annual inflation rate fell for a fourth consecutive month, dropping to 2.5 percent in March from 2.9 percent in February. Excluding energy and food costs, core inflation rose at a1.7 percent annual rate last month, compared with 2 percent in February, and was lower than economists had expected. Food, rather than energy, has been mainly responsible for pushing the consumer price index higher -- a typical trend during the winter months. With little inflationary pressure, further cuts in interest rates to stimulate a cooling economy are expected from the Bank of Canada. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Rises'}
snippet: Canada's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, accelerated to 4.3 percent in the 12 months to November, the biggest rise in several years, Statistics Canada said. The increase in the year to October was 3.2 percent. The surge was m...
lead_paragraph: Canada's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, accelerated to 4.3 percent in the 12 months to November, the biggest rise in several years, Statistics Canada said. The increase in the year to October was 3.2 percent. The surge was mostly a result of energy prices, which fell in the fall of 2001, leading to a lower base for comparison. Measured on month to month, the index rose at a more modest rate of 0.2 percent in November. Excluding energy, inflation rose by 3.5 percent in the year to November, reflecting advances of more than 10 percent in auto insurance premiums and cigarette prices. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'Canada-Venezuela Talks'}

lead_paragraph: LEAD: Marcel Masse, Canada's Energy, Mines and Resources Minister, began talks this week with top Venezuelan oil officials to promote cooperation in oil matters. Mr. Masse's five-day visit, which began Sunday, is the first ministerial level contact in five years between this member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and Canada, an independent producer.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Oil Rift Imperils Project'}
snippet: Work on a $12 billion oil-sands project in northern Alberta will probably halt if that province and the federal Government in Ottawa cannot break their impasse over energy prices by the end of this month, a project spokesman said today.   Glen Rai...
lead_paragraph: Work on a $12 billion oil-sands project in northern Alberta will probably halt if that province and the federal Government in Ottawa cannot break their impasse over energy prices by the end of this month, a project spokesman said today. Glen Rainbird, public affairs officer for Esso Resources Canada Ltd., manager of the planned facility, said that company officials may decide the project's fate after a meeting between the federal Energy Minister, Marc Lalonde, and his Alberta counterpart, Merv Leitch, scheduled for late this month.

headline: {u'main': u'Amoco of Canada Sees Spending Drop'}

lead_paragraph: The Amoco Canada Petroleum Company, a wholly owned unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said the impact of the Canadian Government's national energy program and the Alberta government's oil production cutbacks will result in a 56 percent drop in exploration and production spending in 1981. Besides a new federal levy on oil and natural gas production, the cornerstone of Canada's new energy program, Amoco Canada also cited the Alberta government's oil production cutback of an average 60,000 barrels a day as a factor in reduced production.

lead_paragraph: The largest stock offering in Canadian history closed today amid much fanfare, with the Canadian Government gaining proceeds of $1.3 billion for the sale of most of its stake in the energy giant Petro-Canada. The oversubscribed sale of 123.9 million shares was described by Petro-Canada's president and chief executive, Jim Stanford, as a major turning point for the oil company, created in the 1970's as part of a nationalistic energy policy.

headline: {u'main': u"Results PlusKafelnikov Takes Title in Australia   Top-seeded and sixth-ranked Yevgeny Kafelnikov defeated Byron Black, seeded eighth, 7-6, (7-0), 3-6, 6-1, in the final of the Australian Hardcourt in Adelaide. It was the second time in three years Kafelnikov won the title. Black, a doubles expert who is ranked 40th in singles, said his effort in winning the second set cost him energy in the final set. (AP)    KORDA CAPTURES QATAR OPEN: Petr Korda of the Czech Republic beat Younes el-Aynaoui of Morocco, 7-6 (7-5), 2-6, 7-6 (7-5), to win the Qatar Open in Doha. It was the 27-year-old Czech's seventh career title and came just three months after a hernia operation to cure him of a nagging groin injury that bothered him for 18 months. Korda's ranking will move from 41 to 27 today. El Aynaoui, who defeated top-seeded Thomas Muster in the semifinals, had only appeared in one final before, in Casablanca in 1993. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Long Island Runner a Double Winner Rob Hiller of Farmingdale, L.I., captured the 1,500-meter (4 minutes 21.6 seconds) and 3,000-meter (9:33.7) runs yesterday in the Metropolitan Athletics Congress high school track events at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Teaneck,  N.J. Three other Long Island athletes won in girls' competition. Ronale McKenzie of St. John the Baptist took the 55 meters in 7.9 seconds, teammate Lynn Merjuck was first in the 1,500 in 5:33.4, and Rose Suener of Great Neck North won the 800 in 3:00.3. The open events were canceled because to the weather.    MEET RECORDS FALL AT DARTMOUTH RELAYS: Bruny Surin of Canada and Cheryl Brantle of Boston set meet records in the 55-meter dashes at the Dartmouth Relays in Hanover, N.H. Surin, the world indoor champion, broke his 1993 mark of 6.17 seconds by winning his semifinal heat in 6.15. Surin then won the final in  6.16. Brantle won the women's final in 6.93, breaking her 1993 meet record of 6.95. Rebecca Grube of the Boston Athletic Association set a meet record in the long jump with a leap of 20 feet 3 3/4 inches. (AP) SKIING Tomba Wins Third Straight Slalom     Alberto Tomba, the three-time Olympic gold medalist, won in Flachau, Austria, yesterday to take his third consecutive World Cup slalom race. He was timed in 1 minute 41.05 seconds. Mario Reiter of Austria, who led Tomba by .36 seconds after the first run, finished second at 1:41.25. At this time last year, Tomba had won five slaloms and two giant slaloms en route to 11 victories during the 1994-95 season. (A"}
