headline: {u'main': u"HNG WRITE-OFF SET ON PERU OIL ASSETS CHICAGO, Dec. 30 - HNG/Internorth Inc. said today that it expected to take a large write-off because of the nationalization of its Belco Petroleum operations in Peru.   The Belco unit was seized last Saturday after the company and the Peruvian Government failed to reach an agreement on exploration spending and a tax rate. Another threatened company, Occidental Petroleum, worked out a new contract with Peru, agreeing to expand exploration in return for additional acreage.   On Aug. 29, just after its contract with Peru expired, Belco is said to have cut its production to about 20,000 barrels a day from 30,000 barrels.   Although Belco's operations in Peru have a book value of $400 million, industry analysts said the parent corporation was expected to take a substantially smaller charge.   ''They're going to take a loss of somewhere between $100 million and $200 million,'' said David N. Fleischer, a vice president with Prudential-Bache Securities. Mr. Fleischer and other analysts based their estimates on the company's liabilities after taxes, the expectation of a settlement with the Peruvian Government and proceeds from insurance.   HNG/Internorth, which is based in Omaha, has assets of $10.5 billion, and it earned $165.2 million for the first nine months of 1985 on revenues of $8.02 billion. In the first quarter, HNG earned $113.8 million on $2.90 billion in revenues, of which the Belco unit contributed $19.9 million in earnings, deriving about 24 percent of that from its Peruvian operations. HNG did not report Belco's earnings separately in the second and third quarters.   Both the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investment Service affirmed Internorth's ratings today. S.&P. said that its ratings covered $1.9 billion of debt and that the company's senior debt holds a BBB rating. Moody's pointed out that although the exact financial effect of Peru's move was uncertain, some compensation from the Latin American nation was expected.   Separately, HNG/InterNorth said it was withdrawing a proposed offering of 9 3/4 percent notes due in 1992. It said the takeover of Belco's Peruvian operations made it impractical to close the offering today as scheduled.   Belco, which has energy operations in the United States and Canada, is reportedly discussing new exploration with the Governments of Ecuador, Indonesia and Australia."}
{u'main': u'Canada Group Bids For Abitibi Shares'}
snippet: Federal Commerce and Navigation Ltd., a Montreal-based shipping and energy group, said it planned to offer $27.50 a share for up to 2,250,000 common shares of Abitibi-Price Inc., a major pulp and paper producer.   The Canadian-owned company said i...
lead_paragraph: Federal Commerce and Navigation Ltd., a Montreal-based shipping and energy group, said it planned to offer $27.50 a share for up to 2,250,000 common shares of Abitibi-Price Inc., a major pulp and paper producer. The Canadian-owned company said it now owned 9 percent of AbitibiPrice common shares and also intended to subscribe to 330,000 shares of Abitibi-Price's recent offering of convertible shares. It added that, assuming full conversion of these and purchase of the additional shares, its stake in Abitibi-Price would be about 20 percent.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada: Trade Surplus Narrows', u'print_headline': u'Canada: Trade Surplus Narrows', u'content_kicker': u'World Business Briefing | Americas'}
snippet: Canada’s trade surplus narrowed in October, as exports to the United States fell to the lowest level in two years because of falling energy prices. The surplus narrowed to 3.8 billion Canadian dollars ($3.3 billion) from a revised 4.5 billion Ca...
lead_paragraph: Canada’s trade surplus narrowed in October, as exports to the United States fell to the lowest level in two years because of falling energy prices. The surplus narrowed to 3.8 billion Canadian dollars ($3.3 billion) from a revised 4.5 billion Canadian dollars in September, Statistics Canada said. Exports fell 1.7 percent, to 37.3 billion Canadian dollars. Imports increased for the first time since July, advancing 0.4 percent, to 33.5 billion Canadian dollars.

headline: {u'main': u'BENIGN INFLATION IN CANADA', u'kicker': u'WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS'}
snippet: Inflation rose at an annualized rate of 2.1 percent in Canada in August, the highest in two and a half years, the Government said, but that was largely because of higher gasoline prices. Excluding food and energy costs, the core rate of inflation ...
lead_paragraph: Inflation rose at an annualized rate of 2.1 percent in Canada in August, the highest in two and a half years, the Government said, but that was largely because of higher gasoline prices. Excluding food and energy costs, the core rate of inflation rose at an unexpectedly low annualized rate of 1.6 percent, down from 1.7 percent in July. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The TransAlta Corporation, a power producer based in Calgary, will offer about 654 million Canadian dollars ($592 million) in cash to buy Canadian Hydro Developers to expand generation from renewable energy. The offer of 4.55 Canadian dollars a share will be made directly to shareholders on Wednesday after Canadian Hydro rejected it, Stephen G. Snyder, chief executive of TransAlta, said. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Quebec Plans Power Plants'}
snippet: Quebec, Canada's largest electricity producer, said it would spend $22.5 billion by 2015 to increase energy output by about 10 percent. Hydro-Quebec, the provincially owned utility, will build dams and power plants able to produce 4,500 megawatts ...
lead_paragraph: Quebec, Canada's largest electricity producer, said it would spend $22.5 billion by 2015 to increase energy output by about 10 percent. Hydro-Quebec, the provincially owned utility, will build dams and power plants able to produce 4,500 megawatts of hydroelectricity, the Quebec government said. Construction will start by 2010 and create 70,000 jobs, the government said. The generating capacity will allow the utility to sell to Ontario and the Northeast United States, which have both forecast dwindling supplies over the next two decades.

headline: {u'main': u'MODERATE INFLATION IN CANADA', u'kicker': u'WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS'}
snippet: Driven mainly by higher prices for natural gas and fuel oil, Canada's annual inflation rate rose to 2.8 percent in October from 2.7 percent in September, less than analysts had forecast. Excluding energy, consumer prices rose 0.1 percent in each o...
lead_paragraph: Driven mainly by higher prices for natural gas and fuel oil, Canada's annual inflation rate rose to 2.8 percent in October from 2.7 percent in September, less than analysts had forecast. Excluding energy, consumer prices rose 0.1 percent in each of the last two months, a 1.5 percent annual rate. Gasoline prices fell but natural gas jumped. Timothy Pritchard

headline: {u'main': u'Obama in Canada', u'kicker': u'The Caucus'}
snippet: The trip is expected to focus on the fragile world economy....
lead_paragraph: President Obama arrived in Canada Thursday morning for the first foreign trip of his administration, a visit that is expected to focus on the fragile world economy, the sagging auto industry, international trade, the war in Afghanistan and energy - in particular the question of how to turn Alberta's oil sands into a clean source of power. The Times's Sheryl Gay Stolberg reports from Ottawa.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economy Stalls'}
snippet: Canada's economy stalled in November, Statistics Canada reported, with gross domestic product adjusted for inflation unchanged from the previous month. Strong performances in the housing and energy sectors were offset by lower mining output and mo...
lead_paragraph: Canada's economy stalled in November, Statistics Canada reported, with gross domestic product adjusted for inflation unchanged from the previous month. Strong performances in the housing and energy sectors were offset by lower mining output and motor vehicle sales. Many economists predict that the Bank of Canada will cut interest rates for the second time this year at its next review of monetary policy, on March 2. The Canadian economy grew 1.8 percent in the first 11 months of 2003, compared with the period a year earlier. Bernard Simon (NYT)

The surplus narrowed to 3.8 billion Canadian dollars ($3.3 billion) from a revised 4.5 billion Canadian dollars in September, Statistics Canada said. headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Slows'}
snippet: Canadian inflation slowed to a 12-month low of 2.2 percent in July, removing lingering fears that inflation is still a force to be reckoned with and paving the way for lower interest rates. Core inflation, which strips out volatile food and energy...
lead_paragraph: Canadian inflation slowed to a 12-month low of 2.2 percent in July, removing lingering fears that inflation is still a force to be reckoned with and paving the way for lower interest rates. Core inflation, which strips out volatile food and energy prices, fell to 1.8 percent, below the midpoint on the Bank of Canada's 1 percent to 3 percent target range.

headline: {u'main': u"World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Alcan's Profit Rises"}
snippet: The Alcan aluminum and packaging group reported net fourth-quarter earnings of $143 million, up from $26 million a year earlier. Operating earnings grew by 9 percent. Alcan, based in Montreal, said that the benefits of higher metal prices and impr...
lead_paragraph: The Alcan aluminum and packaging group reported net fourth-quarter earnings of $143 million, up from $26 million a year earlier. Operating earnings grew by 9 percent. Alcan, based in Montreal, said that the benefits of higher metal prices and improved productivity had been offset by the weak dollar and rising energy and pension costs. The results do not include any contribution from Pechiney, the recently acquired French aluminum producer. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: EnCana Sells Gas Storage Business'}
snippet: EnCana said a private equity fund had agreed to pay $1.5 billion for its natural-gas storage business. The company, based in Calgary, Alberta, said the storage business was being bought by the Carlyle/Riverstone Global Energy and Power Fund, owned...
lead_paragraph: EnCana said a private equity fund had agreed to pay $1.5 billion for its natural-gas storage business. The company, based in Calgary, Alberta, said the storage business was being bought by the Carlyle/Riverstone Global Energy and Power Fund, owned by Riverstone Holdings and the Carlyle Group. Next month, the fund will acquire EnCana's storage facilities in Alberta, Oklahoma and Louisiana. The sale of EnCana's installation in California is subject to review by the state's Public Utilities Commission.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Drop In Profit For Commercial Printer'}
snippet: Shares of Quebecor World Inc., a commercial printer, fell 25 percent after it forecast a steep drop in first-quarter profit and its newly appointed chief executive resigned for personal reasons. Blaming weak print markets in North America and Euro...
lead_paragraph: Shares of Quebecor World Inc., a commercial printer, fell 25 percent after it forecast a steep drop in first-quarter profit and its newly appointed chief executive resigned for personal reasons. Blaming weak print markets in North America and Europe, and high energy prices, Quebecor World said it expected first-quarter net income of $24 million to $29 million, or 12 cents to 15 cents a diluted share, below the median estimate of 32 cents a share from seven analysts polled by Multex Inc.

headline: {u'main': u'Tenneco Of Canada Up for Sale'}
snippet: Tenneco Inc. announced yesterday that it planned to sell its Canadian subsidiary, which accounts for about 3.7 percent of its annual production of oil and about 2.5 percent of its annual production of natural gas.   Although the company, in its st...
lead_paragraph: Tenneco Inc. announced yesterday that it planned to sell its Canadian subsidiary, which accounts for about 3.7 percent of its annual production of oil and about 2.5 percent of its annual production of natural gas. Although the company, in its statement, did not explain why it had asked the New York securities firm of Morgan Stanley & Company to seek buyers for Tenneco Oil of Canada Ltd., analysts attributed the move to a Canadian energy policy designed to discourage foreign ownership of its energy resources. Under this policy, Canadian-owned concerns are given tax and exploration incentives that are not available to foreign-owned companies. As a result, a number of United States companies have sold their Canadian energy holdings in recent months, including Conoco Inc., the St. Joe Minerals Corporation and the Allied Corporation.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Interest Rate Raised'}
snippet: Responding to unexpectedly strong domestic growth, the Bank of Canada raised its trend-setting overnight rate yesterday for the third time this year, to 2.75 percent from 2.5 percent. The central bank said the Canadian economy had been moving towa...
lead_paragraph: Responding to unexpectedly strong domestic growth, the Bank of Canada raised its trend-setting overnight rate yesterday for the third time this year, to 2.75 percent from 2.5 percent. The central bank said the Canadian economy had been moving toward full production capacity more quickly than anticipated. The core inflation rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy categories, was 2.2 percent in May, slightly higher than the bank's 2 percent target. Bernard Simon (NYT)

snippet: A selling wave hit Canadian-based oil and gas issues yesterday, causing sharp declines in the sector of the stock market that has shown the most spectacular price gains in recent years.         Canadian energy stocks had benefited in the past from...
lead_paragraph: A selling wave hit Canadian-based oil and gas issues yesterday, causing sharp declines in the sector of the stock market that has shown the most spectacular price gains in recent years. Canadian energy stocks had benefited in the past from the skyrocketing price of Middle East oil, plus their image as ''politically safe'' investments that were also hedges against inflation. As a result, analysts noted, some issues rose in price as much as 700 percent since 1978.

headline: {u'main': u'OIL DRILLERS FLEE CANADA FOR U.S.'}
snippet: From Houston to Calgary, the two gleaming continental energy capitals, sister cities lying 1,600 miles apart at opposite ends of the North American oil region, the word is out: Driller, come south.         And the drillers are coming - in droves. ...
lead_paragraph: From Houston to Calgary, the two gleaming continental energy capitals, sister cities lying 1,600 miles apart at opposite ends of the North American oil region, the word is out: Driller, come south. And the drillers are coming - in droves. Canadians and Americans alike, many of those who hunt for oil and natural gas, are beginning to flee booming western Canada. They are engaged in what promises to become a huge shift of money and drilling rigs from the hydrocarbonrich but relatively unexplored prairies, pine forests and muskeg of Alberta and Saskatchewan to the Rocky Mountains and Southwestern flatlands of the United States.

lead_paragraph: A sharp drop in sales of natural gas by Canada to the United States has prompted the Government to reconsider a price increase that was to have been announced next week. A spokesman for the Ministry of Energy, Mines and Resources said a statement would be issued next Monday. The industry, however, is understood to be expecting a postponement of an increase beyond the present $4.47 (in United States currency) per thousand cubic feet.

snippet: BP Canada Inc. agreed over the weekend to sell its refining and marketing activities to the Government's Petro-Canada for $347.5 million (Canadian). The deal would double Petro-Canada's share of the market, to 12 percent.   The announcement set of...
lead_paragraph: BP Canada Inc. agreed over the weekend to sell its refining and marketing activities to the Government's Petro-Canada for $347.5 million (Canadian). The deal would double Petro-Canada's share of the market, to 12 percent. The announcement set off an immediate political protest because Petro-Canada must borrow the money to pay for the 16,400 gasoline stations and a refinery in Ontario. BP Canada plans to close a second refinery in Montreal next May.

headline: {u'main': u'Amoco Canada Property Swap', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: The Amoco Canada Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Amoco Corporation, and two other energy companies agreed to swap interests in about 5,000 oil and natural gas properties in western Canada worth about $1 billion (Canadian), or about $850 mil...
lead_paragraph: The Amoco Canada Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Amoco Corporation, and two other energy companies agreed to swap interests in about 5,000 oil and natural gas properties in western Canada worth about $1 billion (Canadian), or about $850 million (United States). Amoco Canada said the exchange with Calgary-based Encor Inc. and Maligne Resources, a subsidiary of the Dow Chemical Company, was the largest one-time property swap in the history of the petroluem industry. No money will change hands, because each of the companies is putting up properties that are about equal in value. The intent is to give each company a larger working interest in lands in which it already has a stake, an Amoco spokesman, David Annesley, said. "In some lands where we had partnerships with Encor and Maligne, we now effectively have eliminated those partners and taken on sole interest." The property exchange is part of Amoco Canada's move to form a new public company, Crestar Energy, by combining a portion of its petroleum assets with Canandian assets held by Dow Chemical. Shares in the new company are expected to be made public by mid-1994.

snippet: CALGARY, ALBERTA CANADA has yet to take the world's energy crisis  seriously. Canadians burn up more energy on a per capita basis than any other industrialized country, including its profligate neighbor to the  South. The President of Mexico is du...
lead_paragraph: CALGARY, ALBERTA CANADA has yet to take the world's energy crisis seriously. Canadians burn up more energy on a per capita basis than any other industrialized country, including its profligate neighbor to the South. The President of Mexico is due in Ottawa in late May, officials announced last week, to talk further about, among other things, Canada's desire to buy 100,000 barrels of crude oil a day for 10 years.

headline: {u'main': u'ECONOMICALLY, THINGS LOOK THAT MUCH WORSE IN CANADA'}
snippet: TORONTO FROM the idle shipyards of the Maritimes to the lines of unemployed industrial workers in Ontario and the depressed grain markets in the prairies, Canada's economy is on the skids - high inflation, growing unemployment and flagging product...
lead_paragraph: TORONTO FROM the idle shipyards of the Maritimes to the lines of unemployed industrial workers in Ontario and the depressed grain markets in the prairies, Canada's economy is on the skids - high inflation, growing unemployment and flagging production. Compared to the United States, Canada's bad news is worse; inflation is nearly double the American rate, unemployment is one-fifth higher and interest rates are steeper. Explanations are many. It is common wisdom that interest rates must be higher in Canada than in the United States if investment is not to flow southward. Canadian labor costs are comparatively high and as a supplier of resources, Canada is vulnerable to global economic downturns. Then there is the argument, pressed by the Reagan Administration, that Canada has shot itself in the financial foot by imposing nationalistic measures. Critics - including Gulf Oil, which last week cited the plan as a principal culprit in laying off 300 workers - have suggested that the two-year-old National Energy Program has added to inflation, stimulated interest rates and helped bankrupt small oil companies and their suppliers.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada: Factory Sales Rise, but Are Still Low', u'kicker': u'World Business Briefing | AMERICAS', u'print_headline': u'Canada: Factory Sales Rise, but Are Still Low', u'content_kicker': u'World Business Briefing | AMERICAS'}
snippet: A rebound in car sales lifted Canadian manufacturers’ sales in January, rebounding from a three-year low set a month earlier. Statistics Canada said factory shipments rose by 1.3 percent, to 49.3 billion Canadian dollars ($49.8 billion), after s...
lead_paragraph: A rebound in car sales lifted Canadian manufacturers’ sales in January, rebounding from a three-year low set a month earlier. Statistics Canada said factory shipments rose by 1.3 percent, to 49.3 billion Canadian dollars ($49.8 billion), after sliding 3.7 percent in December. With the exception of December, though, factory sales were still at their lowest since March 2005, as manufacturers struggled to compete amid a strong Canadian dollar, higher energy prices and the downturn in the United States. Excluding auto sales, which rose 4.5 percent, factory sales gained 1.1 percent in January. Auto sales fell 25.6 percent in December to the lowest level in almost a decade.

headline: {u'main': u'PETROLEUM PLACE, INTERNET CONCERN, IN CANADA DEAL', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Petroleum Place Inc., an Internet energy portal and market maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Applied Terravision Systems Inc. of Canada, a provider of integrated financial accounting and property asset management software and ser...
lead_paragraph: Petroleum Place Inc., an Internet energy portal and market maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Applied Terravision Systems Inc. of Canada, a provider of integrated financial accounting and property asset management software and services, for $69 million in stock. Petroleum Place, based in Englewood, Colo., provides integrated Internet-enabled products and services, supporting online oil and gas asset databases, geotechnical data and negotiated transaction services. Applied develops enterprise information solutions that manage revenue-generating assets with complex ownership. (Bridge News)

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Oil Pipeline'}
snippet: The Canadian energy group Enbridge announced plans to broaden the market for oil from Alberta in the United States by building a $600 million pipeline from northern Wisconsin to southern Illinois. The line, scheduled for completion in 2007, will c...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian energy group Enbridge announced plans to broaden the market for oil from Alberta in the United States by building a $600 million pipeline from northern Wisconsin to southern Illinois. The line, scheduled for completion in 2007, will connect with an existing pipeline between Chicago and Oklahoma, whose flow is being reversed to southbound from northbound. Canada's output of crude oil is expected to grow from 2.7 million barrels a day to 3.4 million over the next decade as it extracts more oil from deposits of oil sands. Enbridge said that the pipeline, with an initial capacity of 250,000 barrels a day would give it access to the St. Louis area and to Kentucky. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'Canada: Pipeline Break Spews Oil Onto Vancouver', u'kicker': u'World Briefing | Americas', u'print_headline': u'Canada: Pipeline Break Spews Oil Onto Vancouver', u'content_kicker': u'World Briefing | Americas'}
snippet: Environmentalists were assessing damage to land and seawater in suburban Vancouver as a cleanup of oil sprayed from a ruptured pipeline continued. An excavator working on a sewer line on Tuesday broke the pipeline, sending a plume of crude oil abo...
lead_paragraph: Environmentalists were assessing damage to land and seawater in suburban Vancouver as a cleanup of oil sprayed from a ruptured pipeline continued. An excavator working on a sewer line on Tuesday broke the pipeline, sending a plume of crude oil about 60 to 100 feet into the air until the system was shut down 25 minutes later. Eight homes in Burnaby were heavily coated by the oil and remained evacuated. Several oil-saturated streets remained closed. Storm sewers caused some oil to enter Burrard Inlet, although light winds and the rapid placement of containment barriers limited its spread. The Canadian Transportation Safety Board is investigating. The pipeline is owned by Kinder Morgan Energy Partners of Houston.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Grows'}
snippet: Helped by higher prices for energy exports and by lower imports, Canada's current account surplus widened to 6.1 billion Canadian dollars ($4.4 billion) in the first quarter, from 5.4 billion Canadian dollars ($3.9 billion) in the previous three m...
lead_paragraph: Helped by higher prices for energy exports and by lower imports, Canada's current account surplus widened to 6.1 billion Canadian dollars ($4.4 billion) in the first quarter, from 5.4 billion Canadian dollars ($3.9 billion) in the previous three months and $4.4 billion Canadian dollars ($3.2 billion) a year earlier, Statistics Canada reported. On the financial account, foreigners invested heavily in bonds denominated in Canadian dollars, in contrast to the previous three years when the most popular Canadian bonds were in United States dollars. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Edges Higher'}
snippet: Canada's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, rose 1.3 percent in the year to June, with a sharp rise in cigarette prices partly offset by lower gasoline and natural gas costs, Statistics Canada said. The index advanced 1 percent ...
lead_paragraph: Canada's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, rose 1.3 percent in the year to June, with a sharp rise in cigarette prices partly offset by lower gasoline and natural gas costs, Statistics Canada said. The index advanced 1 percent in the year to May. Excluding energy prices, which were 10.4 percent lower than a year ago, the index rose 2.6 percent in June. Statistics Canada said lower mortgage rates also dampened the increase. Higher tobacco taxes made up more than half of the rise, with cigarette prices up 32.1 percent from a year earlier. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Sinopec Invests in Oil Sands'}
snippet: The Sinopec Group, a Chinese oil and gas producer, said its Canadian subsidiary had purchased a 40 percent holding in a proposed oil sands project in Alberta. Through a series of transactions, SinoCanada will pay 149.7 million Canadian dollars ($1...
lead_paragraph: The Sinopec Group, a Chinese oil and gas producer, said its Canadian subsidiary had purchased a 40 percent holding in a proposed oil sands project in Alberta. Through a series of transactions, SinoCanada will pay 149.7 million Canadian dollars ($119.4 million) for the stake in the Northern Lights Project, which was entirely owned by Synenco Energy of Calgary. If developed as planned, the project, which Synenco has been promoting for nearly two years, will produce 100,000 barrels of crude oil a day and cost 4.5 billion Canadian dollars to develop over five years. The companies said that the investment had been approved by both the Chinese and Canadian governments. Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Prices Up by 12.8 %'}
snippet: Canadian consumer prices in June rose 12.8 percent above prices in June 1980, surpassing the previous record increase of 12.6 percent in April, Statistics Canada reported today.   Higher food, housing and transportation costs were largely responsi...
lead_paragraph: Canadian consumer prices in June rose 12.8 percent above prices in June 1980, surpassing the previous record increase of 12.6 percent in April, Statistics Canada reported today. Higher food, housing and transportation costs were largely responsible for the increase, the federal agency said, the latter two largely because of a 4.9 percent price rise in energy-related products. Food prices, which registered a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent between early April and early May, jumped by 1.8 percent between early May and early June.

snippet: The EnCana Corporation, a Canadian natural gas producer, agreed to buy out its partner in an East Texas gas field for $2.55 billion, its largest acquisition in three years, to increase its presence in one of the fastest-growing sources of the fuel...
lead_paragraph: The EnCana Corporation, a Canadian natural gas producer, agreed to buy out its partner in an East Texas gas field for $2.55 billion, its largest acquisition in three years, to increase its presence in one of the fastest-growing sources of the fuel in the United States. EnCana said it had acquired the stake in the field, located about 80 miles northwest of Houston, from Leor Energy, which is privately held. EnCana, which is based in Calgary, said it planned to accelerate drilling there next year by adding three rigs to the seven now in service.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Falls'}
snippet: Inflation in Canada fell to its lowest level in more than a year in October, slipping below the midpoint of a central bank target range as energy prices declined, Statistics Canada reported. But analysts said the below-target October inflation rat...
lead_paragraph: Inflation in Canada fell to its lowest level in more than a year in October, slipping below the midpoint of a central bank target range as energy prices declined, Statistics Canada reported. But analysts said the below-target October inflation rate of 1.6 percent was unlikely to alter their expectations of unchanged Canadian interest rates. The Bank of Canada, which aims to hold inflation at the midpoint of a 1 percent to 3 percent range, expects growth to pick up next year, and that could increase inflationary pressures again. Statistics Canada said October inflation, down from 2.2 percent in September, was the lowest since June 2002.

headline: {u'main': u'VINTAGE PETROLEUM INCREASES ITS HOLDINGS IN CANADA', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Vintage Petroleum said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Genesis Exploration, a Canadian producer of oil and natural gas, for $572 million. The move enables Vintage, based in Tulsa, Okla., to bolster its presence in western Canada. Vintage w...
lead_paragraph: Vintage Petroleum said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Genesis Exploration, a Canadian producer of oil and natural gas, for $572 million. The move enables Vintage, based in Tulsa, Okla., to bolster its presence in western Canada. Vintage will pay $11.62 for each share of Genesis, based in Calgary, Alberta. The offer is a 22 percent premium to Genesis's closing price on Tuesday of 15 Canadian dollars ($9.56) on the Toronto stock exchange. Last year, Vintage, which owns oil and gas fields, acquired Cometra Energy, which has fields in Alberta and British Columbia, for $46.3 million.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Gas Price Rise'}
snippet: Canada's Energy Minister, Marc Lalonde, hinted today that Canada might raise  the price of the natural gas it sells to the United States. Mr. Lalonde said in  a speech to an American Gas Association meeting that Canada has not changed its  export ...
lead_paragraph: Canada's Energy Minister, Marc Lalonde, hinted today that Canada might raise the price of the natural gas it sells to the United States. Mr. Lalonde said in a speech to an American Gas Association meeting that Canada has not changed its export price since February, when it was raised to $4.47 (United States) per thousand cubic feet. ''We can't continue our restraint much longer,'' he said. Earlier this year, Canada postponed a gas price rise to $5.14 per thousand cubic feet because of competition from cheaper American gas and fuel oil.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Declines'}
snippet: Canada's inflation rate unexpectedly dropped to 1.9 percent in August from 2.3 percent a month earlier, Statistics Canada said. The government agency said that the decrease was mostly caused by falling gasoline prices. After rising 18 percent annu...
lead_paragraph: Canada's inflation rate unexpectedly dropped to 1.9 percent in August from 2.3 percent a month earlier, Statistics Canada said. The government agency said that the decrease was mostly caused by falling gasoline prices. After rising 18 percent annualized in July, gasoline costs increased by 7.8 percent last month. Automobile prices fell by 2.6 percent because of manufacturers' incentives intended to clear out 2004 models. A separate consumer price index that excludes energy and other products with volatile prices was slightly more stable. It rose 1.5 percent in August after reaching 1.9 percent in July. Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: LNG Terminal Is Planned'}
snippet: Repsol YPF, the Spanish energy company, has agreed with the privately owned Irving Oil to build a liquefied natural gas terminal in St. John, New Brunswick, where Irving is based. When completed in 2008, the terminal could ship one billion cubic f...
lead_paragraph: Repsol YPF, the Spanish energy company, has agreed with the privately owned Irving Oil to build a liquefied natural gas terminal in St. John, New Brunswick, where Irving is based. When completed in 2008, the terminal could ship one billion cubic feet a day of natural gas to customers in North America. Irving would market the gas in Atlantic Canada. Repsol, based in Madrid, will take the liquefied gas to the terminal by tanker and will handle sales in the United States and the rest of Canada. The plant, which Irving said would cost $600 million, will be owned by a newly formed company, Canaport LNG. Its major regulatory approvals have been issued. Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA TO SELL MOST OF ITS STAKE IN PETRO-CANADA', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Petro-Canada, the energy giant, said yesterday that the Canadian Government would sell most of its 70 percent stake in the company in a sale that could raise $1.2 billion. Petro-Canada said the Government would sell 118 million shares and set an o...
lead_paragraph: Petro-Canada, the energy giant, said yesterday that the Canadian Government would sell most of its 70 percent stake in the company in a sale that could raise $1.2 billion. Petro-Canada said the Government would sell 118 million shares and set an over-allotment of 5.9 million additional shares if the offering is oversubscribed. The sale could cut the Government's stake to 20 percent, Petro-Canada said. The sale had been expected for some time, and the Government had said early in August that it had selected the brokers to handle the sale.

lead_paragraph: Americans think of Canadians as good neighbors - when they think of them at all. But lately, good neighbor Canada has gotten decidedly fussy about who sniffs its rose bushes. Angry business leaders on this side of the border call for reciprocal limits on Canadian purchases of American mineral wealth.

headline: {u'main': u'TAX LEVIED BY CANADA IN OIL RIFT'}
snippet: The conflict over energy policy between the federal Government and the province of Alberta intensified today when the central Government placed a special tax on crude oil and blamed Alberta for having forced the levy.   Ottawa said the added tax r...
lead_paragraph: The conflict over energy policy between the federal Government and the province of Alberta intensified today when the central Government placed a special tax on crude oil and blamed Alberta for having forced the levy. Ottawa said the added tax revenue was needed to pay for an increase in crude oil imports to offset a 10 percent cut in production yesterday by Alberta. Marc Lalonde, Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources, blamed Alberta's government for the tax, saying the federal Government had had to respond to the province's ''regretta@ble'' decision to cut output. The tax will be levied nationwide and passed on to retail product prices. The effect on consumers works out to about 1.7 cents a gallon (United States funds). A gallon of regular unleaded gasoline in Ottawa now costs about 92 cents.

lead_paragraph: Late last month, Peter M. Towe, Canada's ambassador to the United States, began a speech on relations between the two countries in the traditional fashion. ''We are two nations sharing a continent,'' he said. ''We share prosperity, fears and many values. We also share a great deal of history.'' Then Mr. Towe added a sentence that probably reflects more accurately Canada's recent feelings about its neighbor to the south. ''Some of this history,'' he said, ''is not at all about sharing.''

headline: {u'main': u'U.S.-CANADA TENSION MOUNTS'}
snippet: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada will meet with President Reagan tomorrow against a backdrop of mounting resentment by American business over discriminatory Canadian investment and energy policies. At the same time, Canada faces a t...
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada will meet with President Reagan tomorrow against a backdrop of mounting resentment by American business over discriminatory Canadian investment and energy policies. At the same time, Canada faces a threat by Congress to make things more difficult for Canadian investors here. The Reagan Administration, mindful of benefits that flow from an investment policy, is not supporting any of the retaliatory moves and is calling for more time for the workings of quiet diplomacy. But bills already have been introduced to impose a nine-month moratorium on Canadian acquisitions of more than 5 percent of the stock of American energy companies and to apply to foreigners the same 50 percent margin requirement, or borrowing ceiling for securities purchases, that is required of American investors.

lead_paragraph: In the face of mounting American criticism of Canadian policies limiting investment by foreigners here, the Government was reported today to have postponed plans to strengthen a much-criticized agency that passes on foreign investment applications. But at the same time, Marc Lalonde, Minister of Energy, served notice to the United States that the policy of reducing foreign domination of the oil and gas industry ''is there to stay'' and that ''there is no point in their pursuing this issue any further.'' Furthermore, Ottawa strengthened the political support it enjoys for its Canadianization program by signing an energy pricing and revenue sharing agreement with British Columbia today similar to that signed with Alberta at the beginning of the month.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Cuts Interest Rates'}
snippet: After acknowledging for the first time that Canada is entering a recession, the Bank of Canada cut its key interest rate on Tuesday by three-quarters of a percentage point, to 1.5 percent, a 50-year low.     The lack of a mortgage and banking cris...
lead_paragraph: After acknowledging for the first time that Canada is entering a recession, the Bank of Canada cut its key interest rate on Tuesday by three-quarters of a percentage point, to 1.5 percent, a 50-year low. The lack of a mortgage and banking crisis in Canada had shielded the country somewhat from the economic downturn. But a sharp drop in exports to the United States, particularly of automobiles and auto parts, combined with a collapse in energy and commodity prices has brought it into the point of a recession.

lead_paragraph: Canadian oil companies that went on a takeover binge after the Government decided to ''Canadianize'' ownership of the industry performed far worse last year than other oil companies, a federal agency has found in a survey. The Petroleum Monitoring Agency said Tuesday that the acquiring companies had losses totaling $600 million (Canadian) in 1982, in contrast to profits of $500 million in 1981.

headline: {u'main': u'Oil Reserves Up in Canada'}
snippet: Reserves of conventional crude oil in the western provinces of Canada fell last year to about 5.5 billion barrels, equal to about 12 years' supply at current annual rates of consumption, the Canadian Petroleum Association said yesterday.   But the...
lead_paragraph: Reserves of conventional crude oil in the western provinces of Canada fell last year to about 5.5 billion barrels, equal to about 12 years' supply at current annual rates of consumption, the Canadian Petroleum Association said yesterday. But the association estimated that new fields off eastern Canada held 1.1 billion barrels of recoverable crude, putting the nation's total reserves at about 6.7 billion barrels, up about 800 million from 1980.

headline: {u'main': u'OIL CONCERNS CHA LLENGE CANADA ACCORD'}
snippet: Canada's major petroleum companies declared today that to achieve the national goal of energy self-sufficiency in the next decade they would need more revenue than the federal and Alberta governments planned to allow them.   The Canadian Petroleum...
lead_paragraph: Canada's major petroleum companies declared today that to achieve the national goal of energy self-sufficiency in the next decade they would need more revenue than the federal and Alberta governments planned to allow them. The Canadian Petroleum Association, whose members produce 80 percent of Canada's oil and gas, lamenting a five-year agreement reached Sept.1 between Alberta and Ottawa, called for further negotiation with both governments. ''They have baked a pie and sliced it up,'' one association executive commented. ''We need a bigger slice.'' The energy agreement provides for substantial increases in the price of oil discovered before last January, until it reaches 75 percent of world levels by 1986. It also provides for immediate world prices for new conventional and synthetic oil, and Clem Dumett, chairman of the association, said the increases ''will generate sufficient overall revenue to pay the costs of self-sufficiency.'' But Mr. Dumett noted that ''most of the increased revenues have been appropriated by the governments.''

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Plan for New Oil Sands Project'}
snippet: Imperial Oil filed an application with regulators in Alberta to build an oil sands mine project valued at 4.5 billion to 6.5 billion Canadian dollars. The Kearl Oil Sands project, a joint venture between Imperial, which is almost 70 percent owned ...
lead_paragraph: Imperial Oil filed an application with regulators in Alberta to build an oil sands mine project valued at 4.5 billion to 6.5 billion Canadian dollars. The Kearl Oil Sands project, a joint venture between Imperial, which is almost 70 percent owned by Exxon Mobil, and Exxon Mobil Canada, would produce 100,000 barrels of raw bitumen, the tar that emerges from processed oil sands ore, within five years if approved. According to the filings, that figure would eventually increase to 300,000 barrels a day. At the moment, Imperial's plans do not include an upgrader to turn the bitumen into oil. The project must be approved by the Alberta Energy and Utilities Board as well as the province's ministry of the environment. The mine would be built near the Northeastern Alberta community of Fort McMurray.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Miner Raised'}
snippet: The energy and mining company, Sherritt International Corporation raised its unsolicited bid for a rival, Fording Inc., increasing the cash portion of its 1.77 billion Canadian dollars ($1.13 billion) offer. Sherritt and its partner, the Ontario T...
lead_paragraph: The energy and mining company, Sherritt International Corporation raised its unsolicited bid for a rival, Fording Inc., increasing the cash portion of its 1.77 billion Canadian dollars ($1.13 billion) offer. Sherritt and its partner, the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, are offering 20 Canadian dollars a share in cash, up from 17.63 Canadian dollars, as part of a bid that values Fording at 35 Canadian dollars a share. The remaining 15 dollars would be units in a new income trust holding Sherritt and Fording coal mines. The new offer, the second instances of Sherritt's raising the amount of cash it is willing to pay, is an attempt to persuade shareholders to reject a counterproposal put together by Fording and Teck Cominco Ltd.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA LIFTS GAS EXPORT PRICE'}
snippet: Canadian natural gas imported by American companies will go up in price on Feb. 1, partly as a result of the Canadian Government's efforts to resolve its political problems with the Western provinces.         Canadian gas accounts for about 5 perc...
lead_paragraph: Canadian natural gas imported by American companies will go up in price on Feb. 1, partly as a result of the Canadian Government's efforts to resolve its political problems with the Western provinces. Canadian gas accounts for about 5 percent of United States consumption. Almost all of it goes to the Western and Middle Western states, where companies that import the gas will face a price increase in February from $4.47 a thousand cubic feet to about $4.72. By comparison, the price of natural gas produced in the United States is now well below $4.47 per thousand cubic feet.

headline: {u'main': u'CONOCO TO BUY GULF CANADA RESOURCES FOR $4.3 BILLION', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Conoco has agreed to buy Gulf Canada Resources for $4.3 billion in cash in a deal that would sharply increase Conoco's international oil reserves. The deal, announced yesterday, would strengthen Conoco's energy production and reserves in North Ame...
lead_paragraph: Conoco has agreed to buy Gulf Canada Resources for $4.3 billion in cash in a deal that would sharply increase Conoco's international oil reserves. The deal, announced yesterday, would strengthen Conoco's energy production and reserves in North America and Southeast Asia. The addition of Gulf Canada's proven oil reserves of more than one million barrels worldwide would increase Conoco's total reserves by almost 40 percent. Conoco, based in Houston, would also assume about $2 billion in debt of Gulf Canada, which is based in Calgary, Alberta. Conoco has agreed to pay about $8.02 a share for each Gulf Canada share, or 35 percent more than Gulf Canada's closing share price on Friday.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Plan for New Oil Sands Project'}
snippet: Imperial Oil filed an application with regulators in Alberta to build an oil sands mine project valued at 4.5 billion to 6.5 billion Canadian dollars. The Kearl Oil Sands project, a joint venture between Imperial, which is almost 70 percent owned ...
lead_paragraph: Imperial Oil filed an application with regulators in Alberta to build an oil sands mine project valued at 4.5 billion to 6.5 billion Canadian dollars. The Kearl Oil Sands project, a joint venture between Imperial, which is almost 70 percent owned by Exxon Mobil, and Exxon Mobil Canada, would produce 100,000 barrels of raw bitumen, the tar that emerges from processed oil sands ore, within five years if approved. According to the filings, that figure would eventually increase to 300,000 barrels a day. At the moment, Imperial's plans do not include an upgrader to turn the bitumen into oil. The project must be approved by the Alberta Energy and Utilities Board as well as the province's ministry of the environment. The mine would be built near the Northeastern Alberta community of Fort McMurray. Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank Posts A Charge'}
snippet: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said that it would take a charge of 300 million Canadian dollars ($251 million) to cover costs from lawsuits related to its dealings with Enron, the bankrupt energy company. The bank said that the charge was ...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said that it would take a charge of 300 million Canadian dollars ($251 million) to cover costs from lawsuits related to its dealings with Enron, the bankrupt energy company. The bank said that the charge was a factor in a 14 percent decline in fourth-quarter income. Canadian Imperial, which is based in Toronto, said it earned 439 million Canadian dollars ($367 million) in the quarter. The Enron-related charge was expected. Canadian Imperial paid 80 million Canadian dollars to the Securities and Exchange Commission last year to settle fraud charges related to Enron. The bank also said that it had named Gerry McGaughey as president and chief operating officer. Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u"World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Miner's Profit Falls"}
snippet: Barrick Gold, the Toronto-based gold producer, reported a drop in second-quarter net profit, to $66 million, or 17 cents a share, from $72 million, or 18 cents a share, a year earlier, mostly because of higher energy costs in the western United St...
lead_paragraph: Barrick Gold, the Toronto-based gold producer, reported a drop in second-quarter net profit, to $66 million, or 17 cents a share, from $72 million, or 18 cents a share, a year earlier, mostly because of higher energy costs in the western United States and a lower gold price. The chief executive, Randall Oliphant, above, said higher costs at the El Indio mine in Chile and Goldstrike in Nevada, coupled with lower interest income, would probably result in earnings for the year ''at the lower end'' of earlier estimates of 70 to 75 cents a share. Cash costs for the second quarter rose to $162 an ounce from $144. The average realized price dropped to $340 an ounce from $360, still well above prevailing market prices, thanks to an active hedging policy. Second-quarter output rose to 958,400 ounces from 899,000 ounces. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline:
{u'main': u'Canada: Company Buys Pipe Maker', u'print_headline': u'CANADA: COMPANY BUYS PIPE MAKER

', u'content_kicker': u'Americas'}
snippet: A Canadian steel maker, Ipsco, said it was buying the NS Group, a maker of steel pipes and tubes used in oil fields, for about $1.46 billion. The deal will be used to broaden Ipsco’s sales to the energy industry, the chief executive, David Suthe...
lead_paragraph: A Canadian steel maker, Ipsco, said it was buying the NS Group, a maker of steel pipes and tubes used in oil fields, for about $1.46 billion. The deal will be used to broaden Ipsco’s sales to the energy industry, the chief executive, David Sutherland, said. “This is a transaction that’s all about growth, and if anything, what we will see over the next three years is a growth in the output of all of their facilities, as well as the continuing demand on our own,” Mr. Sutherland said in a conference call. Ipsco agreed to pay $66 a share for the NS Group, which was a 43 percent premium to its closing price on Friday. After the transaction is complete, the new company is expected to have combined annual revenue of more than $4 billion. Ipsco, which is based in Regina, Saskatchewan, and has executive offices in Leslie, Ill., operates three steel mills and six pipe mills in the United States and Canada. The NS Group is based in Newport, Ky.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Miner Raised'}
snippet: The energy and mining company, Sherritt International Corporation raised its unsolicited bid for a rival, Fording Inc., increasing the cash portion of its 1.77 billion Canadian dollars ($1.13 billion) offer. Sherritt and its partner, the Ontario T...
lead_paragraph: The energy and mining company, Sherritt International Corporation raised its unsolicited bid for a rival, Fording Inc., increasing the cash portion of its 1.77 billion Canadian dollars ($1.13 billion) offer. Sherritt and its partner, the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, are offering 20 Canadian dollars a share in cash, up from 17.63 Canadian dollars, as part of a bid that values Fording at 35 Canadian dollars a share. The remaining 15 dollars would be units in a new income trust holding Sherritt and Fording coal mines. The new offer, the second instances of Sherritt's raising the amount of cash it is willing to pay, is an attempt to persuade shareholders to reject a counterproposal put together by Fording and Teck Cominco Ltd.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA LIFTS GAS EXPORT PRICE'}
snippet: Canadian natural gas imported by American companies will go up in price on Feb. 1, partly as a result of the Canadian Government's efforts to resolve its political problems with the Western provinces.         Canadian gas accounts for about 5 perc...
lead_paragraph: Canadian natural gas imported by American companies will go up in price on Feb. 1, partly as a result of the Canadian Government's efforts to resolve its political problems with the Western provinces. Canadian gas accounts for about 5 percent of United States consumption. Almost all of it goes to the Western and Middle Western states, where companies that import the gas will face a price increase in February from $4.47 a thousand cubic feet to about $4.72. By comparison, the price of natural gas produced in the United States is now well below $4.47 per thousand cubic feet.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA ALLOWS NEW GAS EXPORTS TO JAPAN, NOT NORTHEASTERN U.S.'}
snippet: Canada's National Energy Board today authorized substantial new shipments of natural gas to Japan instead of meeting requests from importers in the Northeastern United States.   The American requests that were denied constituted about half the tot...
lead_paragraph: Canada's National Energy Board today authorized substantial new shipments of natural gas to Japan instead of meeting requests from importers in the Northeastern United States. The American requests that were denied constituted about half the total sought by United States importers for the period from 1985 to 1994. The energy board, a quasi-judicial Government agency, assigned the authority for gas shipments to Japan to Dome Petroleum Ltd., which has recently suffered financial setbacks, partly because of worldwide weakness in the oil and gas market. Dome has been negotiating a contract with Japanese importers to help it get back on its feet. Dome said in a statement today from its headquarters in Calgary, Alberta, that the energy board's approval would allow it to press ahead with the permits it needs to construct gas export facilities.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA BUYING UNIT OF PETROFINA'}
snippet: Petro-Canada, the Government-owned oil company, is in the final stages of an agreement to acquire Petrofina Canada Ltd.  from Belgian interests for $1.2 billion (in American funds), the two parties reported today.   The acquisition would be the fi...
lead_paragraph: Petro-Canada, the Government-owned oil company, is in the final stages of an agreement to acquire Petrofina Canada Ltd. from Belgian interests for $1.2 billion (in American funds), the two parties reported today. The acquisition would be the first breakthrough in the Government's campaign, announced last October, to end foreign domination of the country's oil and gas industry. Petro-Canada would acquire the Belgian parent's 71 percent interest in Petrofina, one of the smallest of the foreign-owned oil companies operating in Canada.

headline: {u'main': u'Gulf Canada-Ultramar Talks'}
snippet: Ultramar Canada Inc. said yesterday that it had ended negotiations with Gulf Canada Ltd. to buy Gulf Canada's refining and marketing assets in Quebec and the Atlantic provinces.   William Berry, Ultramar's manager of government affairs, said the n...
lead_paragraph: Ultramar Canada Inc. said yesterday that it had ended negotiations with Gulf Canada Ltd. to buy Gulf Canada's refining and marketing assets in Quebec and the Atlantic provinces. William Berry, Ultramar's manager of government affairs, said the negotiations were called off late Sunday after Gulf Canada rejected Ultramar's bid for the properties, which include 675 service stations in Quebec and the Atlantic provinces and a refinery in Montreal.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Sets Gas Plan'}
snippet: The Canadian Energy Minister, Gerald Regan, announced today that the federal Government had approved what amounts to near-deregulation of the export price of natural gas.   Mr. Regan said the plan, approved Thursday, would allow individual buyers ...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Energy Minister, Gerald Regan, announced today that the federal Government had approved what amounts to near-deregulation of the export price of natural gas. Mr. Regan said the plan, approved Thursday, would allow individual buyers and sellers of gas to negotiate a price on contracts, which would then be given final approval by the National Energy Board.

lead_paragraph: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., seeking to expand its oil production into the British portion of the North Sea, offered $:432 million, or $722 million, today to buy Clyde Petroleum P.L.C., which rejected the bid as ''unsolicited and wholly unacceptable.'' Investors and analysts said the Canadian oil and natural gas producer would have to increase its offer. Higher oil prices and production have increased the value of small energy exploration companies like Clyde, they said.

headline: {u'main': u'PROJECT TO SHIP GAS FROM ARCTIC NEARS APPROVAL IN CANADA'}
snippet: Less than 1,000 miles from the North Pole lies a rich field of natural gas that, by 1986, is expected to flow to homes in eastern Canada and, indirectly, to increase the supply of gas to the United States.   The Arctic Pilot Project, one of Canada...
lead_paragraph: Less than 1,000 miles from the North Pole lies a rich field of natural gas that, by 1986, is expected to flow to homes in eastern Canada and, indirectly, to increase the supply of gas to the United States. The Arctic Pilot Project, one of Canada's boldest attempts to exploit its northern resources, is in the final stages of approval, and construction is to begin when the National Energy Board and the Government give the expected green light in midyear. The project is being proposed by a group of Canadian companies led by the Government-owned Petro-Canada. The other partners are Dome, Nova and Melville Shipping, while Panarctic Oils will produce the gas and TransCanada Pipelines will distribute it.

headline: {u'main': u'A Tech Niche In Canada', u'kicker': u'BITS'}
snippet: Showing how quickly an esoteric technology can become mainstream, Mike Lazaridis and Doug Fregin, who together founded BlackBerry, are establishing a $100 million venture fund for technologies that employ practical applications of quantum physics....
lead_paragraph:
Showing how quickly an esoteric technology can become mainstream, Mike Lazaridis and Doug Fregin, who together founded BlackBerry, are establishing a $100 million venture fund for technologies that employ practical applications of quantum physics. 
 
The fund is based in Ontario, Canada, which they hope to make into a powerhouse for the next great trend in high technology. Though the area is flat, Mr. Lazaridis referred to it as “Canada’s ‘Quantum Valley.’”

headline: {u'main': u'GAS PRICES SET FREE BY CANADA'}
snippet: Canada today announced the deregulation of the price of both domestic and exported natural gas. The move completes the dismantling of the former Liberal Government's energy policy by the year-old Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, a memb...
lead_paragraph: Canada today announced the deregulation of the price of both domestic and exported natural gas. The move completes the dismantling of the former Liberal Government's energy policy by the year-old Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, a member of the Progressive Conservative Party. Last June 1, Ottawa decontrolled crude oil prices under an agreement called the Western Accord. The same petroleum-producing provinces that signed that accord - Alberta, Saskatchewan and British Columbia -signed today's agreement.

A three-hour meeting of United States and Canadian trade and legal experts marked the placing of the long-simmering dispute between the two countries before the international forum of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

headline: {u'main': u'SEPARATISM GROWS IN WESTERN CANADA'}
snippet: Every few nights in the booming cities and towns of oil-rich Alberta, citizens are turning out by the thousands to cheer the idea that Canada's four western provinces ought to separate and be independent         The sudden upsurge in the west of a...
lead_paragraph: Every few nights in the booming cities and towns of oil-rich Alberta, citizens are turning out by the thousands to cheer the idea that Canada's four western provinces ought to separate and be independent The sudden upsurge in the west of a sentiment previously prominent only in French-speaking Quebec is the most extreme expression of what Premier Peter Lougheed is calling Alberta's ''anger and frustration'' with policies dictated by the federal Government in Ottawa. In turn Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who started moves for a new Canadian constitution and a national energy policy, has called the west hysterical.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada to Delay Rise in Gas Price'}
snippet: The Canadian Government, under heavy pressure from natural gas producers, decided today to forgo for now an increase in the gas export price.         American gas importers, which are now paying $4.47 a thousand cubic feet for  Canadian gas, were ...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Government, under heavy pressure from natural gas producers, decided today to forgo for now an increase in the gas export price. American gas importers, which are now paying $4.47 a thousand cubic feet for Canadian gas, were expected to be charged an additional 25 cents starting Feb. 1 to take account of a new tax on all gas sales imposed by the Canadian Government as part of a program to increase the federal share of oil and gas revenues.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Anger at U.S. Over Softwood Lumber Dispute'}
snippet: Any measures, including retaliation, would be fair if they could persuade the United States to respect trade panel decisions on Canadian softwood lumber imports, Foreign Minister Pierre Pettigrew said. ''Any means to get their attention, as far as...
lead_paragraph: Any measures, including retaliation, would be fair if they could persuade the United States to respect trade panel decisions on Canadian softwood lumber imports, Foreign Minister Pierre Pettigrew said. ''Any means to get their attention, as far as I'm concerned, would be fair at this time,'' he said. Mr. Pettigrew, left, repeated Canada's displeasure at the United States' refusal to concede defeat after an Aug. 10 ruling from a North American Free Trade Agreement committee on American duties on Canadian lumber. Ministers have said retaliatory sanctions to recoup the taxes the United States imposed are one option. But Mr. Pettigrew, a former trade minister, reacted cautiously to the suggestion that Canada hit the energy-hungry United States through oil and gas shipments. ''We should do it in a way that will not be to the detriment of Canadian interests,'' he said. ''We have to do it in a way that some U.S. interests will ring their senators and congressmen in Washington to say Canadians deserve better attention.''

The targets of today's raids were all small and midsize brokerage firms.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada in Move on Oilfield'}
snippet: With billions of dollars of oil revenue at stake, the federal Government asked the Supreme Court today to back its claim to ownership of the potentially rich Hibernia field off Newfoundland's shores.   The move, angrily denounced by Newfoundland a...
lead_paragraph: With billions of dollars of oil revenue at stake, the federal Government asked the Supreme Court today to back its claim to ownership of the potentially rich Hibernia field off Newfoundland's shores. The move, angrily denounced by Newfoundland as ''an act of aggression,'' appeared to mean a further delay in developing and exploiting oil resources acknowledged by both sides to be essential to Canada's goal of self-sufficiency by 1990.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA MAY SOON CUT PRICE OF GAS SOLD TO U.S.'}
snippet: The Canadian Government, faced with a possible loss of markets, appears to have decided to cut the price of its natural gas exports to the United States by an amount roughly comparable to the price cut for oil announced last month by the Organizat...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Government, faced with a possible loss of markets, appears to have decided to cut the price of its natural gas exports to the United States by an amount roughly comparable to the price cut for oil announced last month by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Canada, according to trade sources, would reduce the current price of $4.94 per million British thermal units by some 50 cents for volumes now being taken and would also offer temporary discounts to about $3.30 for additional amounts of gas. Energy Minister Jean Chretien, meeting with reporters after talks this afternoon with Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel, expressed Canada's ''flexibility'' on gas export prices but did not directly address the specifics of the reported plan. But Marc R. Lortie, first secretary at the Canadian Embassy, seemed to confirm that this plan, in fact, was what Mr. Chretien had in mind.

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- The Canadian convenience store operator Alimentation Couche-Tard agreed on Wednesday to buy Statoil Fuel & Retail of Norway for $2.8 billion, part of a strategy by the Canadian company to expand into the Scandinavian and Eastern European markets. Under the terms of the deal, Couche-Tard, based in Laval, Quebec, will offer the shareholders of Statoil Fuel & Retail 53 Norwegian kroner, or $9.22, for each of their shares in the company, which operates convenience and gas stations across Scandinavia and Eastern Europe.

lead_paragraph: Despite strained relations with the United States, Canada has agreed in principle to allow the American cruise missile and other weapons to be tested over its territory. A treaty covering weapons testing over the western province of Alberta and other areas is now being drawn up and is one of several recent moves showing Canadian cooperation with important elements of American foreign and military policy. Another example was Canada's support for the recent election in El Salvador, although Ottawa had some reservations about it and has generally held a different perspective than the United States on the Central American situation.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA OIL: SIGNS OF AN UPTURN'}
snippet: Two years after the imposition of a tough national energy policy sent half the nation's oil rigs across the border into the United States, Canada's federal and provincial governments are providing new incentives for the troubled industry and signs...
lead_paragraph: Two years after the imposition of a tough national energy policy sent half the nation's oil rigs across the border into the United States, Canada's federal and provincial governments are providing new incentives for the troubled industry and signs of recovery are beginning to emerge. ''We've bottomed out and we're on the mend,'' said Harold Carlyle, chairman of the Canadian Petroleum Association and senior vice president of Gulf Canada Resources. And G.J. Johnson, head of the Royal Bank's Global Energy and Minerals Group, said, ''The oil and gas industry is solidly on the road to recovery.'' Evidence of improvement includes an increase in the number of working rigs in western Canada to 385 at the end of November from 283 a year earlier; a sharp jump in seismic studies, the first phase of oil exploration, and several significant oil discoveries over recent months. Moreover, analysts foresee a 10 percent acceleration in drilling next year.

headline: {u'main': u'No-Confidence Vote in Canada Threatens U.N. Climate Change Meeting'}
snippet: On the same day Canada is to play host to a crucial environmental conference, Prime Minister Paul Martin's Liberal Party government is expected to fall in a no-confidence vote....
lead_paragraph: Monday was supposed to be the day Canada took the reins of international environmental leadership, playing host to a United Nations climate change conference in Montreal to begin a critical round of negotiations to decide how the world will confront global warming in the coming decades. But now Monday is also the day that Prime Minister Paul Martin's Liberal Party government is expected to fall in a no-confidence vote in the House of Commons. Many of the Canadian cabinet ministers and other members of Parliament who were supposed to attend the conference will now be scurrying to the campaign trail instead.

lead_paragraph: North of the Canadian provinces that line the border with the United States lies the huge, undeveloped expanse of the Yukon and Northwest Territories, stretching from Alaska to Greenland. Within this 1.5 million-square-mile area are scarcely a dozen substantial communities and fewer than 50,000 inhabitants. The lives of those inhabitants could be dramatically affected by a decision that President Carter will soon make on the method of tapping the Alaskan gas reserves.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA PROTESTS TRUCKING BILL'}
snippet: The Canadian Government, already undergoing serious economic strains and deteriorating relations with Washington, is now anxious to avert another thorny issue - legislation approved by the United States Senate that could limit the entry of Canadia...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Government, already undergoing serious economic strains and deteriorating relations with Washington, is now anxious to avert another thorny issue - legislation approved by the United States Senate that could limit the entry of Canadian truckers into new American markets. Like many of the irritants that have cropped up recently to threaten aspects of the tightly interwoven relationship between Canada and the United States, the trucking issue involves a clash of sovereign prerogatives and the threat of retaliatory protectionism. ''We are particularly concerned that the Senate legislation is part of a protectionist bent that is evident in a number of countries in hard times,'' said Kenneth J. Merklinger, an official of the Canadian Ministry of External Affairs, which has protested the Senate action in a diplomatic note. ''On this issue, I think we are clean, and we think that it is unfortunate ground to advance a case.''

headline: {u'main': u'TRADE DISPUTES MAR CANADA-U.S. TIES'}
snippet: Although both sides have made efforts in the past year to soften the rhetoric, the United States and Canada remain at odds on a number of trade and investment issues.   The two nations, which share the closest trade relationship in the world, have...
lead_paragraph: Although both sides have made efforts in the past year to soften the rhetoric, the United States and Canada remain at odds on a number of trade and investment issues. The two nations, which share the closest trade relationship in the world, have clashed recently on matters ranging from lumber shipments to the price of wine. The disagreements, arising from a variety of sources, are aggravated by a weak economy in both nations. A major target of American criticism is Canada's National Energy Program, which tends to resist foreign investment in the Canadian oil industry. A major target of Canadian criticism is Congress, which tends to resist Americans' purchases of foreign goods. (Canadians have objected to ''buy America'' legislation for mass transit equipment, for example.)

headline: {u'main': u'OIL PRICE QUANDARY FOR CANADA'}
snippet: With world oil prices falling, the Canadian Government has acknowledged that it can no longer maintain an 18-monthold oil pricing policy that was intended to insulate consumers from the full impact of soaring prices while raising them gradually.  ...
lead_paragraph: With world oil prices falling, the Canadian Government has acknowledged that it can no longer maintain an 18-monthold oil pricing policy that was intended to insulate consumers from the full impact of soaring prices while raising them gradually. Energy Minister Jean Chretien told reporters Monday that a scheduled price increase of $4 a barrel on July 1, which would apply to more than three-quarters of the oil produced in Canada, would not take place. That increase was mandated by a formula reached by Ottawa and the province of Alberta on Sept.1, 1981. However, another feature of that agreement limited oil prices to 75 percent of the world oil price. Currently, the price for ''old'' oil - discovered before Dec. 31, 1980 - is about 73 percent of the free market price for the previous quarter, the period used to make the calculation. A $4 increase would have pushed the price to about 84 percent of the world level.

headline: {u'main': u'Sole Securities Regulator Urged for Canada'}
snippet: Seeking to end years of bickering over securities regulation in Canada, a government-appointed panel has called for the immediate creation of a single national securities watchdog to replace the array of regional agencies that oversees the country...
lead_paragraph: Seeking to end years of bickering over securities regulation in Canada, a government-appointed panel has called for the immediate creation of a single national securities watchdog to replace the array of regional agencies that oversees the country's capital markets. ''Canada's regulatory structure is out of step with the needs of its capital market participants and with the rest of the world,'' the panel's report, published Wednesday, said. The group, led by Michael E.J. Phelps, a prominent Vancouver businessman, concluded that ''major change is both necessary and overdue.''

headline: {u'main': u'HAS CANADA LOST ITS OIL GAMBLE?'}
snippet: IN ''Iceberg Alley,'' just off the coast of Newfoundland, lies the biggest pool of oil ever found off the East Coast of North America. To plumb it, the Mobil Oil Corporation and its partners must contend with lashing winds, 100-foot waves and ice ...
lead_paragraph: IN ''Iceberg Alley,'' just off the coast of Newfoundland, lies the biggest pool of oil ever found off the East Coast of North America. To plumb it, the Mobil Oil Corporation and its partners must contend with lashing winds, 100-foot waves and ice chunks of a magnitude that sank the Titanic a few miles away. That sort of task is expensive -these days, maybe too expensive. The Mobil group must raise $5 billion to produce oil from the alley that will sell for half the price of five years ago. And now there is a real question as to whether it is worth proceeding. That question is being raised about countless high-cost energy megaprojects throughout this oil-rich country. In the last 10 years Canada has spent billions to recover hard-to-get-at oil, gambling that crude prices would keep going up. But now the dramatic price slides engineered by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have turned the economics of Canadian oil development on its ear. Oil companies here are looking askance at projects that once seemed destined for financial greatness, and may drop some if oil prices do not pick up.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA, TO SPUR SALES, TRIMS EXPORT GAS PRICE'}
snippet: Canada today reduced by 22.8 percent the price of some of the natural gas that it exports to the United States, a move prompted by a sharp fall in American demand.   Effective immediately, the price of gas shipped that exceeds 50 percent of volume...
lead_paragraph: Canada today reduced by 22.8 percent the price of some of the natural gas that it exports to the United States, a move prompted by a sharp fall in American demand. Effective immediately, the price of gas shipped that exceeds 50 percent of volumes authorized under existing contracts will be $3.40 (United States) a thousand cubic feet, $1 below the current overall price. The same reduction will apply to gas sold in excess of 50 percent of 1982 export volumes.

lead_paragraph: Canada's Energy Minister today announced rule changes that would make it easier for foreign investors to buy into Canada's oil and gas industry -- a move that may be linked to the troubles of Olympia & York, the Toronto-based real estate giant. Existing oil regulations, which hark back to nationalistic economic policies of the 1970's and early 1980's, prohibit foreigners from acquiring healthy oil and gas companies with assets of $5 million or more.

headline: {u'main': u'ALSANDS OIL PROJECT IN CANADA IS LOSING YET ANOTHER PARTNER'}
snippet: The troubled $13.1 billion Alsands project to extract crude oil from the vast tar sands of western Canada suffered another serious setback today with the withdrawal of a fifth partner.    Shell Explorer Ltd., owned by the Shell Oil Company of Hous...
lead_paragraph: The troubled $13.1 billion Alsands project to extract crude oil from the vast tar sands of western Canada suffered another serious setback today with the withdrawal of a fifth partner. Shell Explorer Ltd., owned by the Shell Oil Company of Houston, announced that it was withdrawing its 20 percent interest in the project, near Fort McMurray, in northeastern Alberta. Shell Explorer's departure came just a day after Dome Petroleum Ltd. and its affiliate, the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company, withdrew their combined 12 percent interest. Earlier this year, two other partners withdrew; they were Canadian affiliates of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), which held 10 percent, and of the Standard Oil Company of California, with 8 percent.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA ANNOUNCES CUT IN OIL PRICE FOR NOV. 1'}
snippet: The National Energy Board of Canada plans to cut the official price of the light crude oil it exports to the United States by about $1.35 a barrel, to about $27.50, senior Canadian officials said yesterday.    The price cut, to take effect Nov. 1,...
lead_paragraph: The National Energy Board of Canada plans to cut the official price of the light crude oil it exports to the United States by about $1.35 a barrel, to about $27.50, senior Canadian officials said yesterday. The price cut, to take effect Nov. 1, marks the fourth official reduction since Oct. 15 by oil-producing countries. Last week's actions by the three others - Norway, Britain and Nigeria - have prompted an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries next Monday in Geneva.
