headline: {u'main': u'URANIUM INDICTMENTS IN CANADA'}
snippet: The Canadian Government, which helped organize a worldwide uranium cartel in 1972, filed criminal charges against six Canadian companies today for allegedly restraining competition and trade in uranium within Canada.   The Ministry of Justice made...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Government, which helped organize a worldwide uranium cartel in 1972, filed criminal charges against six Canadian companies today for allegedly restraining competition and trade in uranium within Canada. The Ministry of Justice made the charges in a Toronto court five weeks after receiving a secret report from the Ministry of Consumer and Corporate Affairs that found grounds for prosecution. Opposition parties, convinced that the Government itself had operated outside the law, have been demanding that the report be made public. Minister of Justice Jean Chretien had refused to disclose the findings before charges were filed and, presumably, the report will now be released.

headline: {u'main': u'REAGAN ASKS CANADA TREATY ACTION'}
snippet: President Reagan said today that he had asked the Senate to ratify an East Coast boundary treaty with Canada but that he had at the same time asked it to drop consideration of a proposed fisheries agreement.   The fisheries agreement would establi...
lead_paragraph: President Reagan said today that he had asked the Senate to ratify an East Coast boundary treaty with Canada but that he had at the same time asked it to drop consideration of a proposed fisheries agreement. The fisheries agreement would establish limits on catches for various species of fish and shellfish, limits that United States fishermen opposed. The draft treaty, covering both the boundary and fisheries questions, has been held up in Congress since it was signed and submitted for ratification by President Jimmy Carter two years ago.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Finds a Way'}
snippet: Canada has proved Churchill right again; democracy is the worst political system, save for all the others.   Here is a vast and wealthy country that has been unable, for half a century, to agree on how to amend its loosely drawn constitution.  Eve...
lead_paragraph: Canada has proved Churchill right again; democracy is the worst political system, save for all the others. Here is a vast and wealthy country that has been unable, for half a century, to agree on how to amend its loosely drawn constitution. Every change in it had to be enacted by the British House of Commons, meaning that Canada technically remained a colony of the Crown.

snippet: Mr. Mulroney himself is no ideologue. He is a practical centrist committed to maintaining Canada's developed welfare state. And the continental dimension of his victory bears promise of a return to healthy two-party politics in a country too long ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. Mulroney himself is no ideologue. He is a practical centrist committed to maintaining Canada's developed welfare state. And the continental dimension of his victory bears promise of a return to healthy two-party politics in a country too long fractured by the language and separatist issues of Quebec.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA TRIES OIL DECONTROL'}
snippet: Less than three months after Canada decided to phase out 11 years of control over the oil industry, the effects are beginning to show in lower prices and increased production and exports.   Before June 1, the federal and provincial governments con...
lead_paragraph: Less than three months after Canada decided to phase out 11 years of control over the oil industry, the effects are beginning to show in lower prices and increased production and exports. Before June 1, the federal and provincial governments controlled prices, buyers and export levels. The so-called Western Accord between the federal Government and the oil-producing provinces of British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan has put all those functions in the hands of the companies. The agreement, designed to provide oil companies with more cash for exploration and development, deregulated oil prices and began to phase out stiff taxes, among other things.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Finds a Way'}
snippet: Canada has proved Churchill right again; democracy is the worst political system, save for all the others.   Here is a vast and wealthy country that has been unable, for half a century, to agree on how to amend its loosely drawn constitution.  Eve...
lead_paragraph: Canada has proved Churchill right again; democracy is the worst political system, save for all the others. Here is a vast and wealthy country that has been unable, for half a century, to agree on how to amend its loosely drawn constitution. Every change in it had to be enacted by the British House of Commons, meaning that Canada technically remained a colony of the Crown.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Defers Gas Price Rise'}
snippet: OTTAWA, April 16 (AP)--Canada is freezing the price of the natural gas it sells to the United States until Oct. 1 in a bid to spur development of the proposed Alaska Highway gas pipeline, Energy Minister Marc Lalonde announced today. An earlier in...
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, April 16 (AP)--Canada is freezing the price of the natural gas it sells to the United States until Oct. 1 in a bid to spur development of the proposed Alaska Highway gas pipeline, Energy Minister Marc Lalonde announced today. An earlier increase, he said, could have an "adverse psychological impact" in getting the pipeline project started.

snippet: OTTAWA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Federal Government announced tonight a delivery stretch-out plan to keep Canada's multimillion-dollar uranium industry going at least until 1966. The move was taken after the Government failed to persuade the United Stat...
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Federal Government announced tonight a delivery stretch-out plan to keep Canada's multimillion-dollar uranium industry going at least until 1966. The move was taken after the Government failed to persuade the United States to buy more Canadian uranium after present contracts expire in 1962 and 1963.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Is Losing Ability to Fill U.S. Gas Needs'}
snippet: For years, Canada has been the safety valve for the United States natural gas market, pumping supplies across the border to ease shortages and keep prices reasonably stable. But the recent surge in gas prices suggests that the days when Americans ...
lead_paragraph: For years, Canada has been the safety valve for the United States natural gas market, pumping supplies across the border to ease shortages and keep prices reasonably stable. But the recent surge in gas prices suggests that the days when Americans could look north for relief are over. Barring a serious slump in the American economy that would significantly reduce demand, industry experts say, the United States will need every cubic foot of Canadian gas it can get, and then some. But Canadian production is, for the moment at least, at its maximum: it will be at least five years before Canada will again be in a position to act as a swing supplier, the experts say.

headline: {u'main': u'HUSKY OIL OF CANADA TO SELL ITS U.S. UNIT'}
snippet: Husky Oil Ltd. of Calgary announced today that it will sell its United States subsidiary -with assets valued at nearly $1 billion - so that it can concentrate on its Canadian operations and on domestic exploration.   Husky's announcement said the ...
lead_paragraph: Husky Oil Ltd. of Calgary announced today that it will sell its United States subsidiary -with assets valued at nearly $1 billion - so that it can concentrate on its Canadian operations and on domestic exploration. Husky's announcement said the company's board ''has decided to approach a selected list of companies in connection with the possible sale'' of the Husky Oil Company, its American subsidiary. It has retained the First Boston Corporation as its adviser. The subsidiary is an integrated oil and gas company, with headquarters in Cody, Wyo., and listed reserves of 36 million barrels of crude oil and 96 billion cubic feet of natural gas. It owns the equivalent of 1.4 million acres, mostly in the West, and has three refineries, in Cody and Cheyenne, Wyo., and North Salt Lake, Utah, with a combined capacity of 60,000 barrels a day.

headline: {u'main': u'CANDIDATES VAGUE ON CANADA DEFICIT'}
snippet: At first glance, the two main candidates for Prime Minister of Canada seem tailor-made for business. Both John Turner, the incumbent and Liberal Party leader, and Brian Mulroney, leader of the opposition Progressive Conservative Party, are former ...
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the two main candidates for Prime Minister of Canada seem tailor-made for business. Both John Turner, the incumbent and Liberal Party leader, and Brian Mulroney, leader of the opposition Progressive Conservative Party, are former corporate lawyers and argue strongly for free enterprise. But as the campaign for the Sept. 4 election enters its final two weeks, both candidates have emphasized expansion of social programs, more spending on women's concerns and governmental efforts to cut youth unemployment. They have not put as much emphasis on the concerns of industry. In particular, they have not offered specific suggestions for dealing with Canada's soaring Government deficit.

headline: {u'main': u'HUSKY OIL OF CANADA TO SELL ITS U.S. UNIT'}
snippet: Husky Oil Ltd. of Calgary announced today that it will sell its United States subsidiary -with assets valued at nearly $1 billion - so that it can concentrate on its Canadian operations and on domestic exploration.   Husky's announcement said the ...
lead_paragraph: Husky Oil Ltd. of Calgary announced today that it will sell its United States subsidiary -with assets valued at nearly $1 billion - so that it can concentrate on its Canadian operations and on domestic exploration. Husky's announcement said the company's board ''has decided to approach a selected list of companies in connection with the possible sale'' of the Husky Oil Company, its American subsidiary. It has retained the First Boston Corporation as its adviser. The subsidiary is an integrated oil and gas company, with headquarters in Cody, Wyo., and listed reserves of 36 million barrels of crude oil and 96 billion cubic feet of natural gas. It owns the equivalent of 1.4 million acres, mostly in the West, and has three refineries, in Cody and Cheyenne, Wyo., and North Salt Lake, Utah, with a combined capacity of 60,000 barrels a day.

headline: {u'main': u'Shell to Test Capturing Of Carbon In Canada', u'kicker': u'GREEN'}
snippet: HOUSTON - In a bid to make  oil sands  production less polluting, Royal Dutch Shell announced on Wednesday that it would go forward with the first carbon capture and storage project ever tried in the fields of western Canada.   The announcement of...
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON - In a bid to make oil sands production less polluting, Royal Dutch Shell announced on Wednesday that it would go forward with the first carbon capture and storage project ever tried in the fields of western Canada. The announcement of the Quest project after years of study comes just months before Washington will reconsider whether to approve the Keystone XL pipeline to increase imports of heavy oil from the oil sands. Environmentalists have fought the project, arguing that refining and burning oil from the oil sands emit far more carbon than conventional oil.

headline: {u'main': u'DISPUTES AWAIT REAGAN ON CANADA TRIP'}
snippet: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has indicated that he is making President Reagan's forthcoming visit to Ottawa a test of American friendship.   Mr. Reagan's first trip abroad, to start March 10 and last some 27 hours, is being hailed with ex...
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has indicated that he is making President Reagan's forthcoming visit to Ottawa a test of American friendship. Mr. Reagan's first trip abroad, to start March 10 and last some 27 hours, is being hailed with expressions of good will on both sides, but conflicting interests and differing philosophies and world outlooks threaten to limit the success each side is seeking. ''I'm hoping,'' Mr. Trudeau told a news conference last week, ''that the Americans will want to surprise us and say, 'Look, we're really your friends and you're our friends and here's a couple of problems we can solve now and let's do it.' '' The Prime Minister noted the Reagan Administration's ''insistence on being friendly toward your friends before worrying about your enemies'' but warned that ''this doesn't mean they are not going to be hard bargainers.''

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA REORGANIZES ITS GOVERNMENT'}
snippet: With Canada in one of its worst recessions in 30 years, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau reorganized his Government today in an attempt to step up exports and to take greater account of regional economic disparities.   The Ministry of Industr...
lead_paragraph: With Canada in one of its worst recessions in 30 years, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau reorganized his Government today in an attempt to step up exports and to take greater account of regional economic disparities. The Ministry of Industry, Trade an d Commerce was broken up, and the Departmen t of External Affairs under Mark MacGuigan was expanded to include re sponsibility for foreign trade as well as normal diplomatic re lations. The Government said this was part of ''a major national effo rt to aggressively pursue international export markets''for products from all regions. The regional aspect was further emphasized by naming Herbert Gray, until now the Minister of Industry, Trade and Commerce, as head of a new Department of Regional Industrial Expansion. Mr. Gray, a strong economic nationalist, will remain in charge of the Foreign Investment Review Agency, which screens all investment proposals by foreigners and which has been accused in the United States of discriminating against American businessmen.

headline: {u'main': u"THE DREAM OF 'ONE CANADA' IS MIRED IN ONE BIG MESS"}
snippet: Pierre Elliott Trudeau embarked last week on a ''crusade'' to end Canada's 12 percent inflation and the worst economic crisis since the Depression of the 1930's. To succeed, he will need unaccustomed cooperation from skeptical Canadians. He seems ...
lead_paragraph: Pierre Elliott Trudeau embarked last week on a ''crusade'' to end Canada's 12 percent inflation and the worst economic crisis since the Depression of the 1930's. To succeed, he will need unaccustomed cooperation from skeptical Canadians. He seems confident of getting it: When a reporter asked if he had perhaps lost political effectiveness after more than 13 years as Prime Minister, Mr. Trudeau replied coldly, ''No, I haven't given that any thought.'' Others have. The recession, with high inflation, high interest rates and unemployment above 10 percent, has spread fear and unrest among wage-earners, farmers, and small businessmen. But even before the situation became critical, something verging on Trudeauphobia began to replace the Trudeaumania that swept the French Quebecer into office in 1968 and (with only a brief interruption in 1979) has kept him there. The Globe and Mail of Toronto seemed to be speaking for many of Canada's decision-makers when it said, ''Recovery has no chance if Mr. Trudeau stays.'' It added, ''If we are to acquire faith in our potential for recovery, we must have a sign of change more believable than any budget could provide. Such a sign can come only from Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, and it can come only with his resignation. His real failings are many. He can no longer deal with our problem. He is our problem.''

headline: {u'main': u"Canada, at U.N., Proposes a 'Third Way' to Deal With the Iraqis"}
snippet: The Security Council, divided by radically differing Russian and American proposals for dealing with Iraq, began discussion today of a ''third way'' proposed by Canada.    The Canadians are hoping to fill the void between what are basically harden...
lead_paragraph: The Security Council, divided by radically differing Russian and American proposals for dealing with Iraq, began discussion today of a ''third way'' proposed by Canada. The Canadians are hoping to fill the void between what are basically hardened Russian and American policies with new information on which to base future talks on new programs for monitoring Iraqi weapons and insuring adequate supplies of necessary goods to Iraqi civilians.

headline: {u'main': u'Why Derail Trade With Canada?'}

headline: {u'main': u'Inflation Is Exceeding Target Set By Canada'}
snippet: While Americans worry about the risks of a double-dip recession, slack demand and falling prices, the talk north of the border is about the opposite. Consumer demand is strong, inflation is on the high side and there is talk that an interest rate ...
lead_paragraph: While Americans worry about the risks of a double-dip recession, slack demand and falling prices, the talk north of the border is about the opposite. Consumer demand is strong, inflation is on the high side and there is talk that an interest rate increase may be needed this year to slow the pace. Statistics Canada, the government statistical office, said today that consumer prices were 3.9 percent higher in December than they were a year earlier. The core inflation rate calculated by the Bank of Canada, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, rose at an annual rate of 2.7 percent in December, the 10th consecutive month that it exceeded the bank's target of 2 percent.

headline: {u'main': u'DEVELOPING CANADA OIL SANDS'}
snippet: Unlike the United States, where Congress cut off funding for synthetic fuels development on July 31, Canada is pressing cautiously ahead with a number of efforts to develop its substantial oil-sands resources, potentially one of the largest synthe...
lead_paragraph: Unlike the United States, where Congress cut off funding for synthetic fuels development on July 31, Canada is pressing cautiously ahead with a number of efforts to develop its substantial oil-sands resources, potentially one of the largest synthetic fuel endeavors anywhere. ''It is our ace in the hole,'' explained John Zaozirny, energy minister of Alberta, the province that has most of Canada's 1,000 billion barrels of oil in known oil-sands reserves. Some of the oil from those reserves is sold as is, but most that is extracted now is synthesized into a lighter, more conventional crude. Mr. Zaozirny and industry officials say that even with today's eroding oil prices, many oil-sands developments, with their low cost and enormous resources, make economic sense -much more than coal gasification and oil-shale development make in the United States. With considerable governmental help still available on both the Federal and provincial level, they make even more.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA SENDS U.S. MORE GAS'}
snippet: Because of Canada's recent formal deregulation of export prices, its natural gas is beginning to pour across the border in large quantities at increasingly low prices after years of being overpriced compared with American gas.    ''We've seen an i...
lead_paragraph: Because of Canada's recent formal deregulation of export prices, its natural gas is beginning to pour across the border in large quantities at increasingly low prices after years of being overpriced compared with American gas. ''We've seen an immediate volume increase, and see the prospect of an even greater one,'' a Canadian Government official said. The Nov. 1 Canadian deregulation came two months before the United States Government is scheduled to increase the proportion of gas output removed from price controls to half, from less than 10 percent, under its six-year-old deregulation schedule. Downward Push Expected In today's soft market, that can only push American gas prices, already weak, downward. Experts say Canada might raise its share of the American gas market to 8 percent, from 4 percent.

headline: {u'main': u'TORIES IN CANADA WIN A BIG VICTORY OVER THE LIBERALS'}
snippet: The opposition Progressive Conservative Party of Brian Mulroney scored a huge victory over the Liberal Party of Prime Minister John N. Turner today in voting for a new national government.     With some results in from every district, the Tories w...
lead_paragraph: The opposition Progressive Conservative Party of Brian Mulroney scored a huge victory over the Liberal Party of Prime Minister John N. Turner today in voting for a new national government. With some results in from every district, the Tories were elected or leading in 211 of the 282 districts nationwide, the Liberals in 40, the New Democratic Party in 30 and an independent in one. The independent, elected in metropolitan Toronto, has said he will turn Tory in the near future. ''Canada has responded to a call to unity,'' Mr. Mulroney told a crowd of widely cheering supporters in his hometown of Baie Comeau. He said the party's mandate was ''to create jobs and get the economy of Canada moving again.'' Mr. Mulroney won his own district of Manicouagan in Quebec's north shore.

headline: {u'main': u'GLOBAL PARLEY IN CANADA IS NOT ALL SMOOTH GOING'}
snippet: A cooperative effort by some 130 scientists from 53 countries to find ways to limit the arms race and reduce international tensions has run into some tensions of its own.   Even before the 31st Pugwash Conference, named after the little Nova Scoti...
lead_paragraph: A cooperative effort by some 130 scientists from 53 countries to find ways to limit the arms race and reduce international tensions has run into some tensions of its own. Even before the 31st Pugwash Conference, named after the little Nova Scotia town where the series began in 1957, opened its sessions in this mountain resort Friday, the organizers protested a decision by the Canadian Government to bar two Soviet delegates. The Department of External Affairs cited security reasons for its refusal to grant the two men visas.

headline: {u'main': u'U.S. SETS GATT PLEA ON CANADA'}
snippet: The United States, which has had a series of sharp exchanges in the past year over Canada's nationalistic trade, energy and investment policies, plans to take its quarrels with Ottawa through the settlement procedures of an international forum.   ...
lead_paragraph: The United States, which has had a series of sharp exchanges in the past year over Canada's nationalistic trade, energy and investment policies, plans to take its quarrels with Ottawa through the settlement procedures of an international forum. President Reagan, on the recommendation of his Cabinet Council on Commerce and Trade, has decided, according to American trade officials, to seek talks with Canada under the formal mechanisms of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The action could lead to recommendations by a GATT panel authorizing the United States to retaliate - provided Washington can prove its case of discrimination - by curbing Canadian access to the American market.

headline: {u'main': u'A New Party in Western Canada Growing on Protest and Populism'}
snippet: Prairie populism, fed by economic disgruntlement, disenchantment with mainline politicians and hostility to power in Ottawa, is energizing a new political party that promises to give the Canadian West a greater say in the way the country is govern...
lead_paragraph: Prairie populism, fed by economic disgruntlement, disenchantment with mainline politicians and hostility to power in Ottawa, is energizing a new political party that promises to give the Canadian West a greater say in the way the country is governed. Attesting to the appeal of the Reform Party in the Oct. 25 elections are poll results, showing it could overtake the New Democrats as this country's third party, with as many as 50 of the 295 seats in the House of Commons. The party now has only one House member.

headline: {u'main': u'Drugs Cost Less in Canada Than in U.S., Study Finds'}
snippet: The General Accounting Office released a study yesterday showing that the prices charged by Canadian subsidiaries of American drug companies were 32 percent lower than the same companies charged American customers.    The study, for the health sub...
lead_paragraph: The General Accounting Office released a study yesterday showing that the prices charged by Canadian subsidiaries of American drug companies were 32 percent lower than the same companies charged American customers. The study, for the health subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, compared 121 drugs. It found that although the prices of 23 drugs were lower in the United States, 98 were higher here, most often by 50 percent or more.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA FOCUSES ON ITS VERSION OF SUPER BOWL'}
snippet: In this quietly fractious country, where the French feel alienated from the English, the agricultural west complains about the industrial east and just about everybody is uneasy over the enormous American influence, many Canadians argue that the p...
lead_paragraph: In this quietly fractious country, where the French feel alienated from the English, the agricultural west complains about the industrial east and just about everybody is uneasy over the enormous American influence, many Canadians argue that the professional football championship game Sunday is a centerpiece reflecting that ephemeral quality known as Canadian nationalism. ''At least once a year, Canada comes together in the spirit of friendly competition, not vitriolic competition,'' Jake Gaudaur, commissioner of the Canadian Football League, said. Added Abraham Rotstein, a political economist at the University of Toronto, ''It represents a gut nationalism, a national binder of an extraordinary kind.'' It all comes together in the fight for the Grey Cup, an unimpressive but coveted silver mug, in a game that to more modest Canadians substitutes for the glossy grandeur of America's Super Bowl. Sunday's game will pit the hometown Toronto Argonauts, champions of the east, against the Edmonton Eskimos, champions of the west.

headline: {u'main': u"Greatest Threat to Caribou Herd in Canada Isn't From Wolves"}
snippet: Humans are a much bigger problem than wolves for a caribou herd in the oil sands area of Alberta, Canada, scientists reported last week in Frontiers in Ecology.      Studies of scat of moose, caribou and wolves in the area showed that caribou acco...
lead_paragraph: Humans are a much bigger problem than wolves for a caribou herd in the oil sands area of Alberta, Canada, scientists reported last week in Frontiers in Ecology. Studies of scat of moose, caribou and wolves in the area showed that caribou accounted for only 10 percent of the animals consumed by wolves. Eighty percent of the wolves' diet was deer, with moose making up the remainder. Wolves' preference for deer, the researchers conclude, draws them away from the areas where caribou thrive.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Raises a Major Interest Rate a Quarter Point'}
snippet: Putting fears of runaway inflation ahead of signs of a faltering economy, the Bank of Canada raised its benchmark interest rate today for the fourth time in a year.    The move, after a vigorous debate among private-sector economists, contrasts wi...
lead_paragraph: Putting fears of runaway inflation ahead of signs of a faltering economy, the Bank of Canada raised its benchmark interest rate today for the fourth time in a year. The move, after a vigorous debate among private-sector economists, contrasts with monetary policy in other developed countries, where authorities have held off on interest rate increases and in some cases have even cut rates in an effort to stimulate economic growth.

headline: {u'main': u'U.S. SETS GATT PLEA ON CANADA'}
snippet: The United States, which has had a series of sharp exchanges in the past year over Canada's nationalistic trade, energy and investment policies, plans to take its quarrels with Ottawa through the settlement procedures of an international forum.   ...
lead_paragraph: The United States, which has had a series of sharp exchanges in the past year over Canada's nationalistic trade, energy and investment policies, plans to take its quarrels with Ottawa through the settlement procedures of an international forum. President Reagan, on the recommendation of his Cabinet Council on Commerce and Trade, has decided, according to American trade officials, to seek talks with Canada under the formal mechanisms of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The action could lead to recommendations by a GATT panel authorizing the United States to retaliate - provided Washington can prove its case of discrimination - by curbing Canadian access to the American market.

headline: {u'main': u'Currency Hits Record Low Vs. Dollar In Canada', u'kicker': u'THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES'}
snippet: A record number of American tourists are making overnight trips to Canada, and for good reason. The Canadian dollar has plunged 5 percent against the dollar since October and dropped to its lowest value ever yesterday, making trips north of the bo...
lead_paragraph: A record number of American tourists are making overnight trips to Canada, and for good reason. The Canadian dollar has plunged 5 percent against the dollar since October and dropped to its lowest value ever yesterday, making trips north of the border much more affordable. Despite intervention by the Bank of Canada to support the currency, the Canadian dollar fell to as low as 68.85 United States cents, or $1.4523 (Canadian) to the dollar. Its previous all-time low was 69.13 United States cents in February 1986. In late trading, the Canadian dollar rebounded a little, finishing at 69.22 United States cents, or $1.4445 (Canadian).

headline: {u'main': u'U.S. OIL COMPANIES CITED BY CANADA'}
snippet: Federal investigators said here today that American oil companies have overcharged their Canadian affiliates by billions of dollars since 1958 in a scheme to reduce their income taxes in the United States.    The report, filed today by the staff o...
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators said here today that American oil companies have overcharged their Canadian affiliates by billions of dollars since 1958 in a scheme to reduce their income taxes in the United States. The report, filed today by the staff of the Restrictive Trade Practices Commission, calculates that the companies overcharged their Canadian units by a total of $3.2 billion (Canadian) from 1958 to 1973, after adjustment for inflation. It asserts that the overcharges have continued since 1973, but largely because of a Government pricing regulation that encourages the overcharges. ''The evidence clearly shows that the Canadian subsidiaries of foreign multinationals were charged excessive prices for the foreign crude they purchased from their parents,'' the agency said in a 800-page report.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Central Bank Leaves Key Interest Rate Unchanged'}
snippet: Citing uncertain prospects for the American economy and turbulent financial markets, the Bank of Canada said today that it would leave its key overnight interest rate unchanged at 2.75 percent after three consecutive increases since April.    The ...
lead_paragraph: Citing uncertain prospects for the American economy and turbulent financial markets, the Bank of Canada said today that it would leave its key overnight interest rate unchanged at 2.75 percent after three consecutive increases since April. The bank said that while ''stronger-than-expected growth in domestic demand in Canada continues,'' prospects for growth in the United States -- where 85 percent of Canada's exports go -- and other major economies ''appear to have weakened somewhat.''

headline: {u'main': u'NASTY MERGER FIGHT IN CANADA'}
snippet: The Unicorp Canada Corporation's bid to take over Union Enterprises Ltd. is a battle that business observers are calling one of the nastiest ever in Canada.    ''It's the kind of thing that brings the whole business community into disrepute,'' Hen...
lead_paragraph: The Unicorp Canada Corporation's bid to take over Union Enterprises Ltd. is a battle that business observers are calling one of the nastiest ever in Canada. ''It's the kind of thing that brings the whole business community into disrepute,'' Henry Knowles, a lawyer and former chairman of the Ontario Securities Commission, said. The battle has seen the authorities decline to prosecute Unicorp for seemingly offering some Union shareholders a lower price than others; Union, as a possible takeover foil, buying a Calgary, Alberta, meatpacker last Thursday at a price far in excess of what Unicorp says it is worth, and relations between the two companies' investment bankers becoming so strained that their heads, half humorously, exchanged presents: a live turkey and a dead duck. Offer Made Feb. 1 Unicorp, an investment concern with interests in real estate and oil, made its offer for Union, which owns a natural gas utility in southern Ontario and oil interests, on Feb. 1. The results of the tender offer will be known Tuesday. Unicorp offered a package consisting of a share of preferred stock and one-half of a nonvoting warrant for common shares.

headline: {u'main': u'OIL DRILLERS OFF CANADA BATTLE NATURE AND POLITICS'}
snippet: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland - A fuzzy dawn is breaking in the foggiest part of the North Atlantic, where four men cling to a basket dangling 160 feet above a choppy, cobalt-blue sea. By stomach-churning tugs, they are being hoisted to their jobs on t...
lead_paragraph: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland - A fuzzy dawn is breaking in the foggiest part of the North Atlantic, where four men cling to a basket dangling 160 feet above a choppy, cobalt-blue sea. By stomach-churning tugs, they are being hoisted to their jobs on the world's largest drilling rig, the 15,000-ton Ocean Ranger. The cargo boat that carried them 14 hours through a stormy night dances below them like an abandoned toy. The mist-shrouded rig, nicknamed the Ocean Danger, looms over them. Its derrick stands as tall as a 35-story building over the water, 14,400 horsepower of machinery pounds relentlessly and 81 crew members scurry about a surface area bigger than two football fields. ''The massiveness kind of terrifies you at first,'' William Aitkenhead, the Ranger's captain, noted later. That is indisputable. But the implications of the activity at the Hibernia K-18 drilling site on the Grand Banks 180 miles off the southeast coast of Newfoundland are considerably larger than the physical magnitude of the rig.

headline: {u'main': u'GAPS IN PROSPERITY TROUBLING CANADA'}
snippet: Mayor Ralph Klein of Calgary, one of Canada's biggest boom cities, has sent shock waves through the country's growing ranks of unemployed by denouncing the ''bums and creeps'' who come to his city looking for work and end up resorting to crime.   ...
lead_paragraph: Mayor Ralph Klein of Calgary, one of Canada's biggest boom cities, has sent shock waves through the country's growing ranks of unemployed by denouncing the ''bums and creeps'' who come to his city looking for work and end up resorting to crime. Mr. Klein, a peppery and outspoken politician and former television announcer, stunned a meeting of the Calgary Newcomers Club Wednesday by threatening to use what he called ''cowboy techniques'' - presumably a roundup - to control the antisocial behavior of some recent arrivals from other provinces. ''Even if we have to put them all in jail, on top of one another, we have to do it,'' he said. The Mayor's remarks served to underline the growing economic and social gap between Canada's regions as western cities like Calgary ride the tide of an energy boom while in the east a deep recession in manufacturing industries is creating some of the highest unemployment levels since World War II.

headline: {u'main': u'Sale Alters the Media Balance in Canada'}
snippet: The Canadian telecommunications company BCE sold most of its stake in Bell Globemedia, owner of Canada's largest private television broadcaster and The Globe and Mail newspaper....
lead_paragraph: The Canadian telecommunications company BCE ended its foray into the media business Friday, selling most of its stake in Bell Globemedia, owner of Canada's largest private television broadcaster and The Globe and Mail newspaper. The sale, for 1.3 billion Canadian dollars and involving three buyers, will alter the balance of power among Canada's media companies. Notably, it will give Torstar, publisher of Canada's biggest newspaper, The Toronto Star, a stake in its rival, The Globe and Mail, a national newspaper with a more affluent readership. Torstar will also gain an entry into broadcasting, something it has long sought.

headline: {u'main': u'U.S. AND CANADA IN ACID-RAIN ACCORD'}
snippet: The United States and Canada agreed today to conduct a joint project to trace the flow of pollutants that cause acid rain.    The agreement, which was signed in Ottawa, addresses one of the major areas of dispute between the two countries.  It cal...
lead_paragraph: The United States and Canada agreed today to conduct a joint project to trace the flow of pollutants that cause acid rain. The agreement, which was signed in Ottawa, addresses one of the major areas of dispute between the two countries. It calls on the two nations to monitor the flow of pollution from industrial plants in Ohio and Ontario, regarded as the prime sources of the pollution that has damaged forests on both sides of the border and killed fish and plant life in hundreds of lakes in New York's Adirondacks as well as in New England and eastern Canada.

headline: {u'main': u'BANKS, CANADA TO AID DOME'}
snippet: Control of Canada's largest independent oil company, Dome Petroleum Ltd., is passing to the federal Government and four of the country's biggest banks as a result of a bailout agreement that provided Dome with $1 billion (Canadian).   Until now, D...
lead_paragraph: Control of Canada's largest independent oil company, Dome Petroleum Ltd., is passing to the federal Government and four of the country's biggest banks as a result of a bailout agreement that provided Dome with $1 billion (Canadian). Until now, Dome has been dominated by John P. Gallagher, chairman of the board and chief executive officer, who started Dome 32 years ago and built it into Canada's largest oil company. He is now Dome's largest single shareholder, with about 4 percent of the stock. The agreement, still subject to approval by the Parliament and by other creditors, gives the four Canadian banks and the Government the right to name a majority of the members of Dome's board, whose 10 current members are loyal to Mr. Gallagher and William Richards, the president.

headline: {u'main': u'NEW INTEREST IN CANADA FOR OIL-SANDS PROJECTS'}
snippet: Development of Alberta's massive oil-sands resource is moving ahead rapidly, after staggering for several years because of stagnant oil prices.    Oil companies are pushing forward on several new or expanded projects to wring the exceptionally hea...
lead_paragraph: Development of Alberta's massive oil-sands resource is moving ahead rapidly, after staggering for several years because of stagnant oil prices. Oil companies are pushing forward on several new or expanded projects to wring the exceptionally heavy crude oil from the sand and subterranean rocks to which it clings. Among the companies, Imperial Oil Ltd., the Amoco Canada Petroleum Company, Petro-Canada and Syncrude, an eight-company consortium, have recently announced developments. The Alberta government has forecast that production of oil from oil sands would rise from almost 170,000 barrels a day last year, to more than 300,000 in 1988.

headline: {u'main': u'RAPID GROWTH AT BELL CANADA'}
snippet: In the three years since its formation as a holding company, Bell Canada Enterprises Inc. has earned a reputation as a hungry corporate acquirer, straying far from its core telephone business.   ''Our pond is very big,'' Jean de Grandpre, Bell Can...
lead_paragraph: In the three years since its formation as a holding company, Bell Canada Enterprises Inc. has earned a reputation as a hungry corporate acquirer, straying far from its core telephone business. ''Our pond is very big,'' Jean de Grandpre, Bell Canada's chairman, said recently. ''We are essentially a Canadian-based international organization.'' Just this month, Bell Canada - the country's most profitable company -set its sights on Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., the big liquor and oil producer. Bell Canada made its bid through Transcanada Pipelines Ltd., in which it holds a 48 percent stake. But, for once, Bell Canada may not get its way. Transcanada withdrew its offer Tuesday - at least temporarily - in the face of a higher bid from the Gulf Canada Corporation, controlled by the Reichmann family.

headline: {u'main': u"U.S. ENVOY'S PARTING WORD TO REAGAN: COURT CANADA"}
snippet: The United States has to be less clumsy and casual and more sensitive and caring in its relations with Canada.  This is the advice that the Ambassador here is preparing to deliver to the new Republican Administration.   At noon on Jan. 20 when Ron...
lead_paragraph: The United States has to be less clumsy and casual and more sensitive and caring in its relations with Canada. This is the advice that the Ambassador here is preparing to deliver to the new Republican Administration. At noon on Jan. 20 when Ronald Reagan is being sworn in, the United States Ambassador to Canada, Kenneth M. Curtis, expects to be following the proceedings on the car radio as he and his wife make the long drive back to their home in Cape Elizabeth, Me., after serving 15 months in Ottawa. A former chairman of the Democratic National Committee as well as a former Governor of Maine, Mr. Curtis, as a political appointee of the Carter Administration, knew his diplomatic career here was over when the election results became known on Nov. 4 and shortly afterwards he submitted his resignation.

snippet: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Nov. 20 - In this little provincial capital, which  has drawn a difficult living from the sea for three centuries, there is growing  optimism that the Atlantic will soon yield riches that the island could only dream of be...
lead_paragraph: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Nov. 20 - In this little provincial capital, which has drawn a difficult living from the sea for three centuries, there is growing optimism that the Atlantic will soon yield riches that the island could only dream of before. Results so far of offshore exploration indicate that Newfoundland, a recipient of financial aid for the 30 years it has been a member of the Canadian Federation, may soon make a major contribution to the nation's oil supply.

headline: {u'main': u"Natives' Land Battles Bring a Shift in Canada Economy"}
snippet: Native bands are exerting increasing control over natural resources across vast stretches of northern Canada....
lead_paragraph: In this rainy land of scarlet dawns and big black bears, workers are busy constructing a 40,000-square-foot extension to a museum that sits in a bushy cove where gray whales come to eat herring and roll over the shell beach to scratch barnacles off their bellies. It is an ambitious project, not least because the hundreds of traditional masks, carvings and blankets the building is meant to display for the native Haida people still belong to some of the world's most prestigious museums. Resistance to the return of artifacts is likely, but the Haida have become used to challenging the rich and powerful, and winning.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA BETRAYS A WEAKNESS FOR WHITE ELEPHANTS'}
snippet: For more than afternoon, the workers at Mirabel International Airport vastly outnumbered the passengers, not an unusual occurrence at Canada's newest, largest, most modern and least-used air terminal.    The footsteps of a solitary visitor sent lo...
lead_paragraph: For more than afternoon, the workers at Mirabel International Airport vastly outnumbered the passengers, not an unusual occurrence at Canada's newest, largest, most modern and least-used air terminal. The footsteps of a solitary visitor sent lonely clacks echoing through the huge empty center hall of the airport complex, which was completed nine years ago at a cost of $430 million. Video screens, mounted every 50 feet or so, indicated there would be only 10 flights arriving and leaving in the next 12 hours, 6 of them connections from Ottawa or Toronto. In the hall, unpopulated expanses stretched in every direction for as far as 200 feet.

headline: {u'main': u'Washington Watch; A Challenge To Canada'}
snippet: THE St. Joe Minerals Corporation has started what could be another altercation with Canada. This time it involves a little-known provision of the Mineral Lands Leasing Act of 1920, which the big mineral extraction corporation wants to use to fend ...
lead_paragraph: THE St. Joe Minerals Corporation has started what could be another altercation with Canada. This time it involves a little-known provision of the Mineral Lands Leasing Act of 1920, which the big mineral extraction corporation wants to use to fend off any new bid by the Seagram Company Ltd. The Fluor Corporation's recent $60-a-share cash and stock package for St. Joe was hastily put together in a merger proposal designed to keep St. Joe out of Seagram's grasp. But fearing a new offer by the huge Canadian distiller, St. Joe has now petitioned Interior Secretary James G. Watt to get Canada stricken from a list of so-called reciprocal countries that may control leases on Federal lands if, under the terms of the statute, they grant the United States ''similar or like privileges.''

headline: {u'main': u'NO ECONOMIC QUARRELS FACE REAGAN IN CANADA'}
snippet: Almost four years ago, President Reagan visited Canada on his first official trip abroad. He came to complain to Pierre Elliott Trudeau, then Prime Minister.    The United States was angry with its neighbor over an energy policy intended to discou...
lead_paragraph: Almost four years ago, President Reagan visited Canada on his first official trip abroad. He came to complain to Pierre Elliott Trudeau, then Prime Minister. The United States was angry with its neighbor over an energy policy intended to discourage foreign ownership and a restrictive attitude toward foreign investment in general and also over aggressive takeover moves by Canadian companies - abetted by the Government and big banks - against American concerns. Four days before that meeting, Washington underscored its displeasure by scrapping an East Coast fisheries treaty between the two nations.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA SETTLES INTERNAL DISPUTE ON PRICE OF OIL'}
snippet: After more than a year of wrangling, the Canadian Government and Alberta, the chief oil-producing province, today reached a five-year accord on oil prices that could end a period of economic uncertainty.   The dispute, which had been recurring ove...
lead_paragraph: After more than a year of wrangling, the Canadian Government and Alberta, the chief oil-producing province, today reached a five-year accord on oil prices that could end a period of economic uncertainty. The dispute, which had been recurring over a decade, has become a symbol of Canada's fractious federalism. Negotiators for the federal Government, which controls the pricing of resources, had warned of a fiscal imbalance as billions of dollars in oil revenue flowed into one region and not into deficit-laden federal coffers. Alberta, which produces 85 percent of the nation's oil and natural gas, jealously guarded its resources and became the symbol of an increasingly assertive West when the old price agreement expired in the middle of last year.

headline: {u'main': u'Investing; A New Investment, Courtesy of Canada'}
snippet: INCOME trusts, which have surged in popularity in Canada, are being offered on the New York Stock Exchange as antidotes to shrinking stock portfolios and tiny fixed-income returns.     The income trusts generally provide rich income streams, as hi...
lead_paragraph: INCOME trusts, which have surged in popularity in Canada, are being offered on the New York Stock Exchange as antidotes to shrinking stock portfolios and tiny fixed-income returns. The income trusts generally provide rich income streams, as high-yield bonds do, but the trusts are actually equity investments. Their value can shift sharply, and the payouts are by no means assured.

headline: {u'main': u'DISMAY IN CANADA AS CURRENCY SAGS'}
snippet: The Canadian dollar has slumped to its lowest level in 50 years, and interest rates have soared to record highs as the pressures on the Canadian economy continue to mount in the face of high American interest rates.   In New York's foreign-exchang...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian dollar has slumped to its lowest level in 50 years, and interest rates have soared to record highs as the pressures on the Canadian economy continue to mount in the face of high American interest rates. In New York's foreign-exchange trading, the Canadian dollar dropped last Thursday to 82 United States cents before closing at 82.156 cents, down from the previous day's 82.21 cents. Shortly after it hit the 82-cent level, the Bank of Canada moved to defend the nation's currency by raising its discount rate, a key interest rate, to 19.89 percent from 19.04 percent, the biggest jump in two months. After the central bank's action, the Canadian dollar recovered somewhat on Friday, closing at 82.24 United States cents.

headline: {u'main': u'U.S. Economy Slows Growth Across Canada'}
snippet: Canada's economy is growing more slowly than expected, but the government will balance its budget anyway, Finance Minister John Manley said today in a speech to a business group here.    Contrasting the fiscal health of his country with the swelli...
lead_paragraph: Canada's economy is growing more slowly than expected, but the government will balance its budget anyway, Finance Minister John Manley said today in a speech to a business group here. Contrasting the fiscal health of his country with the swelling budget deficit in the United States, Mr. Manley said that Canada now expected gross domestic product to grow by 2.2 percent this year after adjusting for inflation, down from the 3.2 percent forecast in February.

headline: {u'main': u'Blocks Seen to Trade Pact With Canada and Mexico'}
snippet: The Bush Administration is almost certain not to seek Congressional approval of a free-trade agreement with Mexico and Canada this year, although it hopes to conclude talks on a pact in the coming months, senior Administration officials said today...
lead_paragraph: The Bush Administration is almost certain not to seek Congressional approval of a free-trade agreement with Mexico and Canada this year, although it hopes to conclude talks on a pact in the coming months, senior Administration officials said today. The officials also said that it seemed increasingly unlikely that there would be a successful conclusion to global trade talks in Geneva this year. Because the United States and the European Community have been unable to resolve their disagreements over agriculture, many countries have stopped negotiating on other issues in the world talks, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said.

headline: {u'main': u'VAST CAPITAL NEEDS FORGED THE MERGER OF 2 CANADA BROKERS'}
snippet: In 1889 A.E. Ames founded a brokerage firm here bearing his name; in 1901 George Cox, Mr. Ames's father-in-law, founded a competing brokerage, Dominion Securities Ltd., which grew over the years into one of this country's leading firms.   That som...
lead_paragraph: In 1889 A.E. Ames founded a brokerage firm here bearing his name; in 1901 George Cox, Mr. Ames's father-in-law, founded a competing brokerage, Dominion Securities Ltd., which grew over the years into one of this country's leading firms. That somewhat distant corporate kinship was recalled last week when the firms announced that A.E. Ames & Company Ltd. would merge with Dominion Securities, creating the largest brokerage house in Canada. The decision to join forces, officials of the two brokerages explained, resulted from the need for access to a substantial amount of capital to handle the increasingly large-scale underwriting projects here, especially in energy-related areas. Anthony S. Fell, president and chief executive officer of Dominion Securities who will have the same positions with the merged firm, Dominion Securities Ames Ltd., said on Monday that in terms of capitalization the new firm would rank No.1 in Canada, ''about 20 percent bigger than Wood Gundy Ltd.'' Wood Gundy has been the largest brokerage here for many years.

snippet: OTTAWA, Sept. 8 -- When Colonel Hanford MacNider came to Canada a little more than two years ago as Minister from the United States he had two objectives in mind. He wanted to see erected in Ottawa an adequate office building for the accommodation...
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Sept. 8 -- When Colonel Hanford MacNider came to Canada a little more than two years ago as Minister from the United States he had two objectives in mind. He wanted to see erected in Ottawa an adequate office building for the accommodation of American Government officials, and he hoped to see completed during his term of office a treaty between the two governments for construction of the St. Lawrence seaway.

headline: {u'main': u'FROM CANADA TO THE BRONX IS NOT EXACTLY KOCH COUNTRY'}
snippet: IN the 165 years since De Witt Clinton became the first Mayor of New York City to be elected governor of the state, nobody else has made the trip from City Hall to Albany. Historic upstate fears of downstate domina tion have played a large part in...
lead_paragraph: IN the 165 years since De Witt Clinton became the first Mayor of New York City to be elected governor of the state, nobody else has made the trip from City Hall to Albany. Historic upstate fears of downstate domina tion have played a large part in that. So even before Mayor Koch outraged some upstaters by ridiculing suburban and rural life in a magazine interview that was published last week, the Koch camp was aware of the difficulties that might arise when the quintessential Manhattanite went stumping north of the Bronx and east of Queens. Assemblywoman Toni Rettaliata of Suffolk County may have spoken for many non-city dwellers in a letter she wrote the Mayor while he was still pondering the question of running.

snippet: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd ordered the dismissal of a detective convicted at a departmental trial of having accepted about $3,500 taken illegally from a narcotics dealer. Detective John Bergersen, 38 years old, under suspension since last...
lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd ordered the dismissal of a detective convicted at a departmental trial of having accepted about $3,500 taken illegally from a narcotics dealer. Detective John Bergersen, 38 years old, under suspension since last month, was accused of having received the money from three other officers in March, 1968, when he was a member of the special investigations unit of the department's narcotics division.
